Battery holder for the Durafly Tundra, It has a 2200mAh Lipo battery for the engine and another 1300mAh for the FPV equipment, it has several holes to vary the center of gravity. To hold the batteries just use a rubber band, and to hold the whole set to the plane, it has a hole to hold objects on the underside of the fvelage, and for the front hitch, you will have to make a drill. I used M3 screws.
Good flights

Soporte de baterías para el Durafly Tundra, Cabe una batería Lipo de 2200mAh para el motor y otra de 1300mAh para el equipo FPV, tiene varios agujeros para poder variar el centro de gravedad. Para sujetar las baterías basta con usar una goma elástica, y para sujetar todo el conjunto al avión, éste dispone de un agujero para sujetar objetos en la parte de abajo del fiselaje, y para el enganche delantero, tendreís que realizar un taladro. He usado tornillería de M3.
Buenos vuelos.

author: shurtcut

title: Harmonograph
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This was made for a Phänomenta held at a public school to display how simple, dampened harmonic oscillations can create interesting patterns. While the mechanics and math behind the phenomenon is extremely complex, the simple construction did spark the interest into natural science in some of the visiting 4th grade children, by simply creating colorful art. In higher classes the same object could be used in its original idea: as an example of a dampened harmonic oscilator.

Parts besides print

2x M3x10 bolt & nuts to set up the lever
1x M6x30 bolt & nut as the weight
non-elastic string
a board with clips to hold a paper
a hexagonal felt tip marker (for example: Stabilo by Pelikan)
500mm (or more) of 15mm outer diameter copper pipe
a weight of about 500g to be mounted in the center of the plate

Screws to fasten the base to a table, a method to mount the weight to the plate

title: 4" To Dual 2" Vacuum / Dust Collector Adapter

description.text:
This is an adapter for a 4" port on a dust collector to two 2" shop vac hoses. I have a router table that has an upper and lower dust collector port, and needed a way to connected them both to the dust collector.

This was printed in ABS and glued with epoxy, and didn't collapse even after connecting the two 2" ports together.

The 'wall' variable in the OpenSCAD file allows setting the thickness of the item.The 2.96mm value is recommended by Slic3R PE when setting the perimeters to 4 and checking the 'Detect thin walls' option.

The 'port_small' and 'port_large' array are just for reference. The actual values are hard-coded within the source. The top and bottom half are connected with a small cube so that the part is manifold and can be printed in one session.

author: brentd27

title: Runcam Micro FPV cam Reinforced case

description.text:
The stock runcam micro shell is very vulnerable. After breaking couple and buying new from runcam I ended up spending a new cam worth of money. So I decided to design my own case.

To prevent light going into the case print at 100%, BLACK!!!, Best results with nozzle 0.2mm printing 0.1mm layers.
The lens opening needs calibration with 7.8 - 7.9mm drill. Otherwise the lens will not fit.

Depending on your quad setup the case can have embedded M2, M2.5 nuts or brash threaded insert. Or drill one more small hole and attach directly with 4 ultra small screws.

I've tried PLA, PETG, Rubber and ABS. ABS was best. Rubber (TPU) as also nice as the lens fit nicely. But Nylon is also possible. Transparent filaments (even slightly) or light color (yellowish) are NO GO - they let too much light.

author: VictorMNA

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3rBokuYkSYd
Just a simple toy that can look like a X, an Y or a Z depending of the way you look at it.

I wanted to switch my FT-5 to using two linear slide rails but my existing Aeroshuttle needed adjusting for it, so I went ahead and tried to add in everything else I had considered doing to make printing easier over the past year. Presenting Aeroshuttle v2!

Features:

  • Designed for E3D Aero
  • Dual rail support
  • BL Touch Mount
  • Integrated cable guides
  • New part cooler for a 50mm blower
  • Integrated nut holders
  • Post to attach a cable guide at the top (as I don't use a cable chain).
  • A guide to keep the stepper wires from rubbing against the belt

The main body uses 2" (and one 2 1/2" #6 screws (as they are easier to source locally here than metric). The blower attaches to the fan mount using M3 screws (I know, I know...).

I've also provided versions of the front plate with no FT-5 logo (in case using elsewhere) and a version with no BLTouch mount (for people who like to do things the hard way).

Enjoy!

Here's our idea for a spooling system which can be attached easily to different platforms.

Still a work in progress, so we're looking for feedback from the community! We've included the Solidworks part file and are open for suggestions.

description.text:
Sorry english makers, i think that's a german issue. That's why wrote only in german.

Das ist der Kennzeichenhalter für mein Gotway MCM2s Wheel. Als Rücklicht habe ich ein "Busch & Müller Akku-LED-Gepäckträgerrücklicht Toplight 2C 326US" verwendet. https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B06XKZX5FM/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Die Bohrungen für das Rücklicht haben nicht ganz gepasst, der der Körper zu dick war und die Muttern nicht mehr aufgeschraubt werden konnten. Ich hatte bis dahin drei Entwürfe gedruckt und hatte keine Lust auf noch ein mal 8 Stunden warten. Ich habe nun M4-Schrauben verwendet. Damit passt das Rücklicht.

Als Befestigung am Wheel habe ich tesa-Spiegelklebeband verwendet. Ich kann das Wheel am Kennzeichenhalter anheben. Der Halter reist nicht ab und ist noch etwas flexibel.

Gedruckt habe ich mit "extrudr green tec"-Filament. Da sich das Kennzeichen bestimmt im Sommer aufheizt und die 60 Grad vielleicht überschritten werden.

Ihr könnt das FS Std-File komplett in FreeCad nach Euren Wünschen ändern.
Wichtig sind dabei die Objekte "Case" und "Holder Final". Aber schaut selbst.

Bei Fragen eifach melden.

CTC Bizer MKS Mod

Oberste feste Schichten: 4
Untere feste Schichten: 4
Kontur-/Umfanghüllen: 4

Wichtig: Bei Schicht 43 eine Pause setzen, damit Ihr die M4-Muttern für das Kennzeichen einsetzen könnt.
In Simplify3D schreibt Ihr bei "Scripte" -> "Start-Script" -> "Zusätzliche Terminal-Befehle für Nachbearbeitung" so etwas ähnliches rein: {REPLACE "\n; layer 43, Z = " "; layer 43\nG28 Y0 X0\nM300\nM25\nG92 E0\nG28 Y0 X0\n; layer 43"}

This is a small lazy susan that might be helpful while working on small art projects. The platform is 75mm in diameter. The top and bottom snap together. I used air soft pellets for the bearings. It would be smoother with 6mm steel bearings but that may also make it rotate too freely. This probably will not scale due to part tolerances and bearing race sizing. I used 10% density supports under the bottom and supports on the overhanging portions of the tabs.

Resolution:

print_settings.Notes:: I also really liked the look of using "concentric" fill for the surface parts, which is supported in Slic3r.  Don't know if that's available in other slicers.

description.text:
This is a more elaborate (perhaps too much so) version of Makefast's TuneFast harp.

Key features of this remix:

  • Reinforcement struts to help prevent bending under string tension
  • Hollow body with resonant cone and F style sound holes
  • Same hardware as original
  • More ergonomic shape
  • No supports required

Note that the resonant cone tends to sound "better" when covered with the palm of your hand when playing. At least IMHO :)

Printer:

Ultibots D300vs

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Note that for best results, you should print the struts in the same orientation as the STL file presents them, and use AT LEAST 1.2mm worth of shell/perimeter. PLA makes a great filament for making the struts, as it's stiffness works better than other "stronger" materials.

I also really liked the look of using "concentric" fill for the surface parts, which is supported in Slic3r. Don't know if that's available in other slicers.

Here's how the struts (in blue) are installed in the body.

You'll want to do a bit of sanding to make sure that the body halves mate well. Having gaps between them will result in a "buzzing" sound when playing :(

Refer to the original at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2709667 for the excellent hardware assembly and tuning instructions provided there.

So I really spent way too much time running the original harp over and over in my head and came up with all sorts of way too impractical ideas to "improve" it. Instead of following through with most of them I just went ahead and did the most I could think of without requiring any new hardware or printing with supports.
keep your keys and things from falling from your pocket

This is a presser foot for sewing invisible zippers. I found that to get the best zipper I had to stitch it once, relaxed, then again pulling against the zipper a little to make sure it opens up the zipper and allows the needle into the little crevice (look up how to sew an invisible zipper.) You could probably do it all in one go, but for me, it was easier in two. For the shaft I had a piece of one of those big black paper clips that had broken. I think it would be a little happier with a slightly larger one. The last picture is the zipper I sewed with it, partially unzipped.

This is my first design, and the second thing I printed (print quality isn't that great in the pics).

remixed_from.author: MAKE
remixed_from.title: Maker Faire Robot Action Figure PIP (with supports): 2015 3D Printer Shoot Out Test Models

description.text:
Print-in-place action figure, derived from the classic Maker Faire Robot Action Figure model.

Key changes:
1) The bottom curved edges have been modified to limit the maximum overhang angle
2) The logos have been replaced with those of FIRST Robotics Team # 862, "Lightning Robotics"
3) The model has been scaled to make the thinnest wall equal to two passes of a 0.4mm nozzle.

Printer:

Dremel DigiLab 3D20+3D40

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Original scale is the minimum recommended size for a 0.4mm nozzle, since this leaves the thinnest wall equal to 2x the nozzle width.

If you will be using a different nozzle width, we recommend for your first step to be to scale the model accordingly. After doing so, feel free to scale larger with increments of 50% (ex. 150%, 200%, 250%...), until you are happy with the final size.

It is important to prevent your slicer from automatically generating supports, as these may interfere with the moving parts. If you experience poor print quality, research alternative solutions like reducing extruder temperature or slowing down the print speed.

At original scale and high-quality slicer settings, this took our printers approximately 2.5 hours to complete.

Removal from print platform

If printing at original scale, the hinges are somewhat fragile. Make sure to loosen the arms and legs from the print bed first, THEN proceed to remove the main body from the print bed.

Note that almost all parts of the model have a small overhang around the edges, so it should be easy to pry each one loose from the print bed.

Moving parts

The following parts can move:
1) Ankle joints
2) Knee joints
3) Hip joints
4) Shoulders
5) Wrists (limited range of motion)
6) Neck

Simply twist each joint to loosen after printing.

Cleanup

Depending on your printer configuration and slicer settings, there may be some cleanup required. We have observed two possible issues:
1) Stringing between the torso and feet
2) Drooping from underside of arms

Warning: The following may be a bit confusing.

This car and its manufacturer are completely figments of my imagination. The manufacturer is called "WagenCorps" and is a joint project between Volvo, Subaru and Cadillac (none of which I own) devoted to the resurrection of the Station Wagon, which had gone extinct by the figment-of-my-imagination future which the car comes from. In this future, the auto industry is mainly devoted to the manufacture of flying cars known as "Air-Drivers", abbreviated to AD in model names. All of my futuristic car models come from this future. Annotated image of marque symbol is enclosed, as are a few explanatory design screenshots.

Stellar is an open-source protocol for exchanging money. Servers run a software implementation of the protocol, and use the Internet to connect to and communicate with other Stellar servers, forming a global value exchange network. Each server stores a record of all “accounts” on the network. These records are stored in a database called the “ledger”. Servers propose changes to the ledger by proposing “transactions”, which move accounts from one state to another by spending the account’s balance or changing a property of the account. The Stellar protocol is supported by a nonprofit, the Stellar Development Foundation.
[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stellar_(payment_network)]

A little robot with movable arms. It should be printed as a single part. The size of piece might need to be increased if the joints don't move. Support shouldn't be needed.

Just another interpretation of a geared cube.
Every Edge of a cube turns into a Gear and of course: Every Corner shares 3 Gears ...
All the Holes are rotated by 20 degrees so you can better assemble it.

You need:

  • 12 M3x16 Screws for the axis
  • 12 M3x4
  • 5 printed holder2
  • 1 printer holdermot
  • 11 printed Gears
  • 1 printed gearmot
  • 1 M3 nut
  • 1 M3x10 skrew for the motor gear

How to assemble:

  • Only Support the Holes of the gears with a Drill. Dont support any other Holes.
  • Connect all the Holders with the M3x4 screws.
  • Connect the Motor Holder last
  • Insert all 11 Gears using the M3x16 screws
  • Insert the M3 Nut and the M3X10 Skrew into the Motor gear
  • Solder Wires to the micro motor
  • Insert the Motor Gear into the Cube
  • Check for correct adjustment of the Motor Axis and Motor Gear and
  • Feed the Motor into the Motor Holder and fix the Skrew in the Motor Gear

Have fun ...

title: Maverick BBQ ET-732 / ET-733 Remote Transmitter Mount

description.text:
If you are familiar with the crappy mount for these remotes, that seem to always let loose and let them hit the ground, I finally bit the bullet to design a more secure mount, that attaches to the same BBQ Guru stainless sheet with 2 easy machine screws and washers. Problem solved. I did not include the holes or countersink so that others can locate the mounting holes for their desired setup. Enjoy!

I designed this with filets on every corner for strength and with a tight fit, so it's almost impossible to dislodge. Not sure how the STL will display and on what axis, but for the best result, print with the base down with supports only.

BTW, the options were not available, but the printer was a DaVince Mini W. Designed in Fusion 360

title: Boss XL/Medium RunCam Eagle Micro Camera Mount

description.text: This is a mount for the Boss XL or Medium frame that will hold the RunCam Eagle micro back a little further in the frame to help protect it in a crash. The hole for the spacers is 4.9mm, instead of 5mm. This will make the fit a little more snug and less likely to slide up or down on the spacers during an impact. If you print this out of something a little stretchy, like TPE, it is perfect fit. If you print it out of TPU, it will fit fine, but will be very tight. In the pictures, the blue is TPE and the orange is TPU. This should work just fine for other micro cameras, like the Swift micro, but it was designed with the Eagle micro in mind.

description.text:
I bought a really good Qi Wireless Fast Charger (made by WallFire) for my car. I'm tell'n you... this thing really STICKS to the dash. I was pretty happy with it, but the place where I wanted to place it slopes upwards ever so slightly.

I think that it was really intended to be mounted upside-down on the windshield, which is not a good option for me. I couln't get it to swivle to a horizontle attitude.

Good thing I have my trusty 3d printer and 20 minutes to spare... yes, the design is a little clunky, but it's all I need. Works great!

Disassembly:
1) Remove the 3 tiny philips crews from under the VERY STICKY suction cup
2) Pop the cover with a small flat-blade
3) Remove the suction cup assembly
4) Unscrew the ball-assembly with a #2 (medium) philips

No need to screw the goose-neck int. I just use a friction fit.

print_settings.Printer:: da Vinci Jr. 2.0 Mix

title: Human Touch HT-1650 Massage Chair Lower Limit Switch Mount

description.text:
For those who own these extremely expensive chairs, and realized the manufacturer will not provide replacement parts, the sting will last a long time. I have had to resort to making my own replacement parts and this is one that I thought some day might save someone a ton of grief to design.

If you are lucky, just the mount itself failed. If the limit switch was destroyed as well, the part number is SS-01GL13 (no E or F) with a simulated roller lever.

I made many revisions and tests so that the limit switch is tight to the housing and fit the internal posts exactly. So, expect to have to tap the switch into the housing to seat. If it's very tight or loose, you might have to scale slightly.

I included a photo of the original broken piece with the new printed piece. It is as close to an exact duplicate as you can make in the critical areas. So far, I have logged many hours of use on the chair and it works great.

It doesn't all me to select the correct printer, by I used a DaVinci Mini W. Part was designed in Fusion 360

description.text:
This is a demonstration of a mechanical setup consisting of a double-rack plate surrounding a sector pinion. Rotation of the center pinion causes alternating linear motion of the rack.

Note that this is not reversible: driving the rack with alternating linear motion will not reliably drive the pinion, as there is a small amount of clearance in the middle of each rotation of the pinion where it is engaged with neither rack.

The setup can be optionally driven by a small hobby gearmotor, available for about $3.25 each on Amazon or about $1.70 each including shipping from AliExpress. They're advertised as Car or Robot motors, and have standard dimensions. This GrabCad Model has proved accurate.

Other hardware needed for assembly includes:

  • 6 @ m3 x 5mm knurled insert nuts
  • 2 @ m3 x 3mm knurled insert nuts (optional)
  • 2 @ m3 x 22mm or 25mm Bolt (I used hex-socket bolts, cap head would also be fine).
  • 4 @ m3 x 6mm Crown head machine screws
  • Two small pieces of wire for motor
  • Single AA Battery Holder
  • Switch (optional)

Both the gear and the rack have a module of 3mm. The pinion has 6 teeth of a 20-tooth gear.

The largest single piece (the racks) fits within a 200mm x 200mm build place easily.

Wanhao Duplicator i3

If you find that the rack has a tendency to "slip" teeth in one direction or the other, there are holes in the end of the rack assembly for additional m3 x 5mm knurled inserts where bolts can be added to limit the travel of the rack.

There are additional holes in the top of the "floor" unit (which holds the motor) for m3 x 3mm threaded inserts, to install a small m3 machine screw through the slots in the rack unit. This captures the rack unit if you want to demonstrate/use this mechanism at an angle. I found this unnecessary for level use.

description.text:
First off all, this is not my idea, the original idea is from JoeyFitzp and can be found here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2502570

This is suitable for 60mm and up inner diameter Led ring lights, these can be found here:
https://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_noss?url=search-alias%3Delectronics&field-keywords=microscope+led+ring+light&rh=n%3A172282%2Ck%3Amicroscope+led+ring+light

I don’t have a 3D printer yet, but I needed a Led light holder for my Amscope SE400Z, for better light and I don’t use the original base, I have a DIY movable boom stand, I don’t have the original led light on gooseneck and the base, that's why I needed another light source.

I send the model made by JoeyFitzp to a 3D printing service but when it came back it did not fit on my Amscope SE400-Z, the 1x objective side was larger on my model and two pieces where optics are on the 1x side where thicker. Since I used to use CAD (not 3D) in the past, I decided to make my own version of it, I made a 3D model send it to the printing service and now it does fit on my microscope, I did some minor changes on the model so last picture you see was the first attempt. Since it was my first attempt I didn’t think about segment on circles and so on.

Updated the pictures, I got my own printer now.

See all my pictures for measurements and the Amscope models.

Video of the adapter with LED ring light:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vlag5i09Fw0

I wanted a way to create parts diagrams with measurements directly from OpenSCAD. I suspect others have done this already, but I couldn't find anything. So I created a library. Just add measurements based on your calculations and parameters, set your view orientation, and export as an image (details in the instructions section) I included an example Servo scad that uses the measurements module to create a parts diagram. As an example, I overly use it to show all orientations. Note, this uses write.scad (thing 16193). You may want to download the latest version directly from thingiverse. I just found this link on the openscad website. It has more features than my library, but does seem to limit to top down view. Not that you can't simply move your object to allow for it's use. Anyway, if you like my library, you would probably like this one too. http://www.cannymachines.com/entries/9/openscad_dimensioned_drawings

• Copy files into the same directory as your .scad file
    Note, this uses write.scad (thing 16193). You may want to download the latest version directly from thingiverse.
  • add use to your file
  • add call to measurement when you want to add a measurement line
  • set the view orientation to what your going to pass in to the measurement method (i.e. front) from the view drop down in OpenSCAD
  • set the view to orthogonal, so everything looks flat
  • flush the caches in OpenSCAD from the design menu
    Note, you only need to do this if you have rendered previously.
  • Compile F5 (note, do not compile and render!)
  • align the view as you want, make sure you don't mess up the orientation. If you do, re-select the one you want from the view menu
  • select export as image from the design menu
    • The parameters to the measurement module are :
    orientation = orientation of measurement line. Values {"horizontal","vertical"}
    view = side of object. Values {"front","left","right","back","top","bottom"}
    Note, this is the same view you select in OpenSCAD
    length = length of measurement
    text = measurement name (keep short)
    textpos (optional, defaults to "below") = position of text above or below the line. Values {"above","below"}
    text_size (optional, defaults to 2) = the size of the text characters in height
    line_thickness (optional, defaults to .15) = the thickness of the measurement line

These parts can be used to make a Bath interferometer used to measure telescope mirrors.
These parts were designed for a 15mm beam splitter, 7.6mm diameter lens, and 13.5 mm diameter laser pointer.

The parts were designed in Fusion360 and that model will be published. It has been parameterized to make lens and laser holders of different sizes.

You can also comment asking for another size and I can upload the .stl far a specific size.

These parts were printed in PLA.

The flat mirror can be glued with RTV silicone to the mirror socket.
The cube is held by friction in the cube holder and is pressed into it to assemble it. It should only be pressed in by hand and finger pressure. It will be a firm fit.
The screw for the socket is a 2-56 screw. All other screws and nut are meant to be 6-32.

There is a hole in the cube holder and base for a 8-32 screw to hold the cube holder to the base but that should not be needed.

a 6-32 screw not shown is used to attach the mirror ball to the base. A 6-32 washer is also a good idea between the head of the cap screw and ball base.

The Fusion360 model has been parameterized so that lens size and laser size can be easily changed. The parameters can be accessed from the Modify menu Change Parameters item.
There are one for lens diameter in mm and laser diameter in mm.

These should be set to about .05 mm larger than the actual lens or laser diameter.
Feb 24 2018 updated fusion360 file with parameterized cube. Cube size now changes base size and cube holder size. Cube size added to parameters under Modify menu.

description.text:
this is a mod to add maganets to make mounting on the fridge easier.
the maganets are speced as follows
Shape: Disc
Width:15 mm
Height: 4 mm
material: any will work, but stronger is better so i used neodymium magnets.
glue: must stick to your material, i used e6000 and printed in PLA

recommended extras.
a half page address lebel.
medium grit sand paper

these are the maganets i am using.
https://tinyurl.com/ya2svg9n (note this is an affiliate link i will get a portion of the sale, it was also really long, so i shortened it)

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Any (i printed in .3mm)

Infill:

20% or more

Notes:

i am using a .8 mm nozzle, and printing in a .3 mm layer height. it printed perfectly.

1) clean any hanging filament from the magant slots, and test fit the maganets.
2) roughen up the insides of the slots with the sand paper.
3) do the same to one of the flat side of the maganets.
4) trim the label to nearly the size, or better yet the exact size (i will eventually upload a stencil for this)
5) rinse off the sand paper pieces left behind, and allow to dry.
6) once dry apply glue to each maganet slot and insert the magantes with the roughend side to the glue.
7) apply the shipping label, and trim if needed.
8) mount roll of paper, pen and put the finished item on full display.

I have a ton of golf pencils and notebooks I keep with me for ideas and design sketches. The short pencils cramp my hands something fierce, but they're dirt cheap and fit everywhere. I leave three or four pencils everywhere, clothes, desks, car, lab, everywhere. So, I made this quick little thing to extend them and store another behind it if needed. You could also add an eraser to the end I suppose. For that though, I prefer to get the pink block erasers and cut them in half to throw in pockets of coats and pants.

There is an extra bit at the bottom to increase bed adhesion, remove it with a sharp razor or pair of side nippers. These are printed in PETG. I recommend multiples of them to be printed together. I designed them to be printed with a standard 0.4 mm nozzle (2 shells).

The inside has small nubs to keep the main pencil held tightly. My golf pencils measure, flat to opposite flat, 7 mm. These were purchased from some Office Max or Depot, or whatever they're called these days, in a big box. Think they had a score in them or so, not sure. Cost me 10 USD if memory serves.

I also made the part cooler modular to test different part cooler shrouds without having to reprint a complete part cooler assembly. I created a rectangular shroud in Tinkercad to test. I have adapted the collar to a Ciicooler for testing as well.

The blower mountings are fitted for 5015 blowers and toolless mounting.

comments.author: adavidson1

description.text:
Inspection tool for FRC 2018 bumpers specifically designed to be lasercut. I mirrored the text for the tiled pieces because I'm using acrylic. I found it easier to read through the acrylic (which I'm using). Ideally this is for 1/4" acrylic (as 1/4" is another useful measurement to have as its the max size of the gap between the bumper and the frame). In the 8 tiled piece version of the file there are 2 which are (laughingly) 'left handed'. They're reversed purely to fit better. I fit 8 pieces on a 12"x12" piece

Note on the Colors: I did blue as a raster, green as vector but at a low power setting because they're just notations and you don't want them to go all the way through. I used the same power setting for the blue raster as I did for the green vectors. The red is a vector cut which goes all the way through the material.

I put tape on the top of the piece so I could then spray paint it and have the words really stand out. Make sure you do a light coating of spray paint and (if needed) multiple layers. If you're too close and get too much paint it will bleed and make the words hard to read. When I did that the first time I ended up taking off the tape and gently cleaning up with acetone. The 2nd time I did a better job with the spray paint and didn't need to take off the tape. I personally, think the 1st batch came out a bit better but also took more time to clean-
probably about 1-2 hours of clean up for 8 pieces. The 2nd batch I just sprayed the tops and probably got 15 done in about 1 hour. The image is of my 2nd batch which was done with just spraying the top of the piece and leaving the paper on.

comments.text: I put masking tape on the front. After I cut the pieces but before I took off the tape I sprayed it with spray paint to make the words stand out a bit more.

description.text: i make this because somebody ask me to doit

This is a soldering station base for the popular TS100 Soldering iron.

There are a few others here on Thingiverse, but I wanted one that would house the power supply as well. I've designed it around popular sized power adapters, and some 1/2" ID copper pipe to absorb the heat. Tolerances are tight, but no sanding should be required as long as your printer is well calibrated. There's storage for 4 replacement tips too. Check the post printing section for helpful details on the pipe and support removal.

I'm including links below for the TS100, 2 options for power supplies ( I use the 19v) that will fit, sponges, and tips. Full disclosure, these are affiliate type links, so if you order through these, it will help me earn some credits toward parts to keep making things like this to share.

Happy Printing and Soldering!

Edit to add: For other soldering irons that might be longer, there's a space for a penny at the bottom of the copper tube to keep from touching the plastic. I had thoughts of adding a flux pot indent above the power supply, and a soldier spool holder in front of that. I personally don't think I'd use them, but I'm curious if others would.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

5%

Notes:

I sliced in Cura with the following settings:

Layer Height .2mm
Wall thickness .8mm
Infill 5% or higher (Lines)
Support: Yes, Grid (25%)

Print time 7 hours 45 min

Hatchbox PLA
Nozzle Temp: 210
Bed Temp: 60
Print cooling started on layer 2

After printing, loosen sponge area supports around the outside with a razor blade or similar and it should pop right out.

For supports in the round tip holder holes, hand drive a standard drywall screw between the support grid for a few threads. With a slight wiggle, the entire support structure should pop right out. I got more of a kick out of this than I want to admit.

There are 2 wall thickness options for 1/2" ID copper pipe, type M and L. This design is for type M (thin wall), which is most common. It will be printed on the side. I've always seen red lettering for type M, blue is type L, but your milage may vary. Cut to 78mm length and deburr. Take care with pressing this into the spiral pipe holder as over exertion could cause layer separation. Twisting helps, sand if you have to.

Links for parts

print_settings.Notes:: I printed the threaded lamp ring with the layer height at 0.1 mm (in order to capture the thread detail), wall thickness at 0.8 mm (with a 'standard' line-width setting of 0.4 mm), top and bottom thickness at 0.6 mm, infill percentage at 20%, and speed at 45 mm/sec.

description.text:
A couple of years ago, my wife purchased two of these five-light floor lamps from 'Bed, Bath, and Beyond': https://www.bedbathandbeyond.com/store/product/studio-3b-trade-5-light-floor-lamp/1013906068?Keyword=floor%20lamp. Some time later, one of the shades from one of the lamps became damaged, and she could not find a replacement. I told her not to worry, because we could just print another one. But what she told me to do instead was not to print a replacement shade, but to print a whole set of them in different colors, and to 'make it look like a bouquet of flowers'.

Either shortly before or shortly after she asked me to make these shades (I don't remember which), I saw a wonderful video from Angus on his 'Maker's Muse' YouTube channel showing how to use the loft feature in Fusion 360 to make vases with organic shapes (https://youtu.be/4UVEDKz2c5w). It seemed to me that the 'vases' that he made would make perfect lampshades for my wife's lamp. So, using the techniques that Angus showed in his video, I made these five lampshades, and my wife and I loved the result.

Also, when it came time to put these lampshades on the lamp, we found that we were missing one of the threaded rings that clamps the lampshade in place. However, this was not a problem either; I simple measured one of the existing threaded rings, and designed my own version of the ring in Fusion 360. The ring worked perfectly. (This awesome video from the YouTube 'CNC Kitchen' channel was very useful to me in helping me to create the threads for this part: https://youtu.be/1nhcKn7Kt8w.)

The colored lampshades in the photos were printed using blue, red, yellow, and purple transparent "AMZ3D-brand PLA filament (available on Amazon.com). The white lampshade was printed using 3D-Solutech 'Natural Clear' PLA (which I also purchased from Amazon). I printed the lampshades on my Anycubic 'pulley-type' Kossel printer, but they can be printed on any decent 3D printer using the 'spralize' or 'vase-mode' setting of your slicer.

As well as the STL files for printing, I have included my Fusion 360 files for all of these parts as well. I specifically designed these shades for our 5-light floor lamps, but with the Fusion 360 files the design could (probably) be customized for hanging lamps and other lamp types as well.

I strongly advise against using incandescent light bulbs with these shades. I found that even the stock plastic shades for this lamp could be damaged by the heat from an incandescent lamp. LED light bulbs will work best, and of late, they have become fairly inexpensive.

I hope the community enjoys printing and using these lampshades. I want to thank my wife for her 'lampshade bouquet' idea (which is something that I would never have thought of on my own), Angus from Maker's Muse for giving me the inspiration for this design, and CNC Kitchen for showing me how to make threads in Fusion 360.

Printer:

Anycubic Kossel, 0.4 mm nozzle

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Note that the lampshade models are not 'shelled'; you must use the Cura 'spiralize outer contour' setting (or vase-mode setting in other slicers) to print the lampshades. I printed mine at a layer height of 0.3 mm, a bottom thickness of 0.8 mm, and a line-width setting of 0.6 mm. (I wanted the wall to be thicker than the 0.4 mm nozzle width in order to make the lampshades stronger, and make the translucent color of the filament show up deeper. When I print in spralize mode, I sometimes will set the line-width to be different from the nozzle width.)

I printed the threaded lamp ring with the layer height at 0.1 mm (in order to capture the thread detail), wall thickness at 0.8 mm (with a 'standard' line-width setting of 0.4 mm), top and bottom thickness at 0.6 mm, infill percentage at 20%, and speed at 45 mm/sec.

UPDATE: Download the 07APR2014 .stl with improved tweaks (see below) (iPhone 5 w/Otterbox stand + Voronoi Yoda) + (headphone + power cable) = Super Efficient phone stand Art! EDIT: 07APR2014 - I have made a slot down the middle of the back for a cleaner look that act as a canal for the cables and is more visually appealing than the cables hanging out the side, also extended the area where the cables hang below the phone to make sure that it should fit nearly all headphones now. I also removed 99% of the side arms so that you can use the phone horizontally if you wish now... you know for youtube and stuff.. Hope you enjoy the new tweaks! I'd like to just design a whole phone stand with only the Voronoi (and I'll may try to approach Dizingof in the future about this). There is enough space for you to set your phone with your headphones and power cable plugged in, in there.. It shoudln't be tight at all with the new tweaks... I loved the iPhone w/Otterbox Defender stand from DDStarkey, but it was missing something that I really wanted... and I really love the Yoda Voronoi from the awesome Dizingof ( If you haven't already checked out his new site go there now!: http://3Dizingof.com ) so much that I had to (try) and put them together and customize them a little too! Hope you enjoy it, and thanks to DDStarkey and Dizingof for their awesome work on these two great items!

MAKE SURE YOU CHECK/PREVIEW YOUR GCODE BEFORE PRINTING!!!!!!  or you may waste about 4 hours of printing and filament just to find out there is a huge section missing :-(  Please load it up in your printer interface and double check the Gcode all the way through to make sure your sliced version is good to go...   
It is pretty hard to slice, but I ran this file through netfabb after several attempts and clicking all the "fixing" buttons on there and got a decent version.

comments.text: I'm hardly an RF engineer, and I haven't received mine yet, but I considered building a two-layer box, putting the board on the internal box, then covering it with tin-foil and placing it inside the outer box for better RF noise immunity.
comments.author: udifink

comments.text: My understanding is for that to work you would have to make sure that the tinfoil shielding is grounded. That's why most true metal cases use grounded screw holes in the board that connect directly to the case. You could probably use the two smaller mounting holes between the outer mount points and the USB port to run a screw that goes through both layers. It'd be really cool to see it done.
comments.author: udifink

comments.text:
Yes, ofcourse the shielding must be grounded, but given the two Antenna connectors, I can probably just pop a piece of the tinfoil over the connector(s) (whose exterior is probably grounded) and screw the antenna over the tinfoil, thereby grounding it.
This would simplify the design of the interior box.
comments.author: jassca

comments.text: Unfortunately the base of the sma connector doesn't smush against the base of the sma post on the radio. I've tried to attach a picture to show what I mean.
comments.author: udifink

comments.text: Maybe printing with a metal- or carbon-filled filament already improves shielding a bit. Although, it would be a quite high resistance for shielding.
comments.author: jassca

comments.text:
I see, but maybe you can still take enough foil out and hopefully screw the antenna over it, the same way a teflon tape is used to seal water pipes.
I haven't got mine yet (just got a tracking number, package not collected by USPS yet), but I'll try it when I get mine.
If it fails, I can always use the grounding holes.

description.text:
This is a cover for the Pen device that comes with Huion H610 Pro Digitising tablet. I transport mine around in a laptop bag and the Pen comes with no cover, the nib looks very sensitive and prone to breakage so this simple cover was born, UPDATE2:
Have removed the ridge on the inside as it was marking the pen, still grips without it and is a nice smooth fit after cleaning the print, there should not be any marking now so just check for rough edges when you fit. UPDATE1:
I've just uploaded the latest iteration and fairly happy with this one, snap fits on the end and a more tapered design that won't easily fall off. NOTE: Use at own risk as may mark your pens finish. If you think its a bit too snug try scaling out the print slightly and clean the inside with a small file to remove any rough edges.
It maybe worthwhile running a small file around the inside just to make sure it won't mark your pens finish from any burrs

description.text:
Wow, recreating all the Fury ships took a lot less time than I originally thought. As a result, I had a go at palette-swapping them to create the Zone Battle skins.
Standard HD ships here.

My personal favourites:
Feisar, Auricom, Qirex, Goteki 45, Triakis, EG-X.
My least favourites:
Piranha, Assegai.

NOTE: Since the Fury EG-X's tail design made it impossible to fit a proper Ø3.2 hole for the jet exhaust, you will need to push it into the horizontal clip plate so that the end of the Ø3.2 shaft faces into the plate instead of along the clip's axis in the traditional fashion. The end result will have the exhaust facing backwards like it does in the LXF files. Part 64727 is ideal as an exhaust piece because although it only comes in opaque colours, it is flexible and thus less likely to damage the horizontal clip plate.

Wipeout belongs to Sony.

Due to the Wii dying in 2019, I decided to make this ornament as a final goodbye to our wii shop channel. Thank you for all the fun, Nintendo.

This thing connectors other things, namely stick things.
Crazy Forts is a brand of stick and ball construction toy and I ran out of balls so I design a replacement. Note it is not exactly the same and using a standard geometrical shape (so it is not a trademark issue to share).

The shape is technically rhombicuboctahedron allowing a very large number of combinations to build add. Holes have been added to the shape and may need a little reaming out fit perfectly, but I haven't had to do much at all.

Printed in carbon fiber because I had some and like black. Something that polishes nicely would be a bit nicer. Also there are larger corners than in the original but everything functions similar.

Basic geometry model was from Agustin Rossi at grabcad:
https://grabcad.com/library/rhombicuboctahedron-2

All design work done in Autodesk Fusion 360 on a Macbook and printed on Kodama Trinus.

description.text:
Mount Calavera in Carlsbad is one of three volcanic plugs in southern Califoria. It is unique in that one side of the mountain was removed by a gravel quarry revealing the columns of dense rock that form the plug. It is now part of the Calavera Nature Preserve; a small restroom and many hiking trails were added. Some parking is available near the eastern end of Tamarack Avenue in Carlsbad.

Here is a model of the cut in the side of the mountain that reveals the innner core.

An incomplete STL image was output from photographs using Autodesk's ReCap Photo. That is the stl file was not a valid one, its back was open and it did not enclose space. A simple fortran program was used to find the unique edges that make a "rim" around the incomplete image. A single vertex was placed behind the open side and triangles created from the rim edges to the new vertex making a valid openSCAD polyhedron command. The resulting STL file was edited in netfabb studio basic.

title: Prusa i3 MK3 Flex3Drive Stepper Mount

description.text:
I have a Flex3Drive Direct Drive Adapter ( https://flex3drive.com/flex3drive/f3d-dda/ ) on the way for my Prusa i3 MK3. The idea is you mount your heavy extruder stepper elsewhere and run a flex drive shaft that is very light and geared at 40:1 to your existing extruder setup.

The Prusa i3 MK3 has mounting holes pre drilled on the left side for a Raspberry Pi. They look to be close enough to provide suitable mounting for the stepper in this application as well.

Work in process, will post an updated STL when I get mine in from overseas and hooked up. Just wanted to post this in advance in case anyone has one on hand they'd like to try.

description.text:
I really like this carriage but I made some changes I thought it needed. Although the zip tie holding the X-carriage belt works I wanted something a bit better and the ability to use an open loop belt. This carriage now has the option of using a open loop belt or the factory closed loop but due to incorporating a belt block the fan wouldn't fit as originally designed. I'll list my modifications and unfortunately I didn't take pictures, sorry. Everything works perfectly. I'll add some pictures of it installed in the next few days.

Mods:
1) Modified the carriage to use LM8UU. This uses (4) short LM8UU linear bearings.
2) Incorporated a belt block and belt fasteners. Here's the link for the belt block I patterned it after. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:619347
3) Modified the fan shroud a bit to allow it to fit and added three mounting posts to screw the fan in due to having to turn the fan to allow it to fit into the carriage as it was designed to do.

I printed this in carbon fiber petg,

comments.author: lukej11

description.text:
Every Rocket needs a nozzle, and converging-diverging de Laval nozzles can accelerate their exhaust gases to supersonic speeds. This Thing allows you to change parameters to design your own optimal rocket nozzle -- just click on the "Customize" button and the rest should be self explanatory. You can find the OpenSCAD source code in the download section, and learn more about the geometry and trigonometry behind the nozzle at:
http://www.waters.to/blog/rocket-nozzles-part-1-the-math/

The area around the nozzle throat seems to be the trickiest part of the print due to the very short layer times. Some things that have worked for me:

  • Increase layer time (and thus cooling time) by printing multiple nozzles at once. I find that printing two nozzles, with one placed upside down, works well for me.

  • Use extra cooling -- point a small fan, or even a stream of compressed air, at the extruder during the layers around the throat.

  • Play with the 'minRadius' setting of the customizer -- this will add extra support material outside the nozzle throat.

KICKSTARTER ALERT!

We're currently running a Kickstarter campaign for the extended range of our ScatterBlocks (quick-assembling miniature terrain), so drop on by and drop us a pledge if you want the full range. For those of you supporting us (or thinking about supporting us) on Patreon, all the rewards will go to our backers there as well (as we do with all our crowdfunding campaigns).

This miniature is a variant of the one that will be included in our new game, Wrath & Ruin (currently in development), a blend of simple miniature wargaming and physical boulder-throwing (check out the videos). We're pretty excited about this one, and would love to get others in on the play testing phase before we expand and go wider with the game. Kickstarter backers at the $25 level and Patreon supporters will get the play tester kit in March (after the current campaign wraps).

The Knight, like all the miniatures we're designing for this game, prints without the need of support material. We printed ours without a raft and at a .1 layer height with 10% infill.

Enjoy!

print_settings.Notes:: I used PLA for this, but I will be making another one in transparent red PETG so that the whole heart will light up.

description.text:
Dishonored Heart, based off a real anatomical human heart, so it's not totally accurate to the game. I found some different picture angles when I was attaching the wire, so the bottom section with the leather patch is pretty different from the in-game.

I also used the following models with some modification to make the gears:
https://sketchfab.com/models/523d4e1ab2c34487a2134aa7161870cc
https://sketchfab.com/models/594f8f2772634a64a1e3bb072d14fae5

Printer:

Creality CR-10S

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Main heart printed with 20% infill, all other parts printed with 100%

I used PLA for this, but I will be making another one in transparent red PETG so that the whole heart will light up.

Assembly.

Superglue the bevel gears together in the orientation you want. I have included a cut-away file so you easily see how I assembled it. I bonded the 2 bone sections to the heart, then painted everything, before I glued all the gears/window to the heart. I gave it a light coating of white Krylon fusion paint as a primer, and acrylic brushed on the color.

I added solid copper wire (scrap house wiring), brass screws, knurled nuts (home depot) and some leather to give it some more realism. You will need to figure out where you want the wires to go and drill your own holes. The barbed wire section is just copper wire with a couple loops to look like barbs, and then I tightly wrapped another piece of wire around it.

I also used a piece of clear plastic (piece of old welding mask shield) bonded to the back of the window frame before I glued the whole window section to the heart. Make sure the inside of the lense is clean before you permanently glue it on.

Semi after the fact, I decided to add an LED tea light to the heart so there is light behind the gear section. This isn't included in the files, since most LED lights/switches will be different. I simply removed most of the tea light casing, and took a hole saw to the back flat section of the heart. I had to pry out some of the infill to make room for the tea light. I then made a cover which screws to the flat section of the heart, and holds the battery in tight. I bonded nuts flush to the flat surface with superglue. The notch in the cover is to access the on/off switch. I have included this cover, but it may not work with your LED light.

LED Tea Light effect. (Sound effects added post production)

remixed_from.title: XYZ Da vinci Y-Carriage ver 2.2 Updated

title: Da Vinci Y-Axis Carriage
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The problem I have with some printer manufacturers is they use closed loop belts so if something were to happen to the belt you're out of luck unless you can source a belt or buy it at an inflated price from the manufacturer.

My goals were to create or modify a carriage to use the factory belt or use an open loop belt which are readily available. My second goal was the ability to replace the rods without having to thread a hole in the end of the new replacement rod. The Da Vinci printer uses a softer rods since bushings are used instead of linear bearings so if you use bearings on the rod it "may" wear out the rod after long usage. You may have to purchase hardened steel linear rods.

The small rectangular opening along side the holes for the linear rods are to fit an M3 nut in and then thread an m3 bolt into the hole on the side, once tightened this will hold the rod into the carriage without the need to thread the ends of your new linear rod.

Both of these carriages use LM8UU short linear bearings. The left carriage is not mine, I modified it for this project. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:658517. The right side was inspired from this design https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2563231 though I started out with a fresh slate.

The belt clamp / mounting was inspired from this design. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:619347

2/26/18 Update:
Printed and did some test fitting of the motor side carriage, seem to be working well. Pictures are shown above.

Added an additional version (motor side Y-carriage) with hole to access rear upper motor mount screw.

Blender Normal Map Repair Process

Download Blender: https://www.blender.org/

Open Blender

On the Main Menu Bar choose: File>Import>Stl (.stl)

Select the .stl you want to repair

With the object highlighted, Press TAB to enter Edit Mode

In Edit Mode, press CTRL+N

Press TAB again to exit edit mode

On the Main Menu Bar choose: File>Export>Stl (.stl)

Note: This process should work for most 3d model types

title: Primbal Session - 3 Axis Brushless Gimbal for GoPro Session

description.text:
*This latest design has not been physically tested

Primbal Session. Finally a gimbal that supports that GoPro Session of yours. This gimbal is based on the Primbal V3 design for the Xiaomi Yi and GoPro 3/4 models.

Primbal V3 implements stronger, stiffer arms that make the gimbal more resistant to vibrations. Additionally, there are now four different isolator options to suite your fancy. The result is a more robust, versatile gimbal to bring you silky smooth video.

This gimbal is composed of 12 printed parts that are all printer friendly. All STLs are in the proper printing position, no reorienting required. All three axis (pitch, roll, yaw) are fully adjustable to perfectly balance the gimbal. This gimbal is designed to best perform with the GoPro Hero and Hero5 Session.

Specs:

Parts:
12 Printed

Hardware:
8 x M2 Bolt 8mm
2 x M2 Nut
4 x M3 Bolt 4mm
2 x M3 Bolt 6mm

Motors:
2804 size for yaw (35mm diameter)
2206/2804 size for roll
2206 size for pitch (28mm diameter)

Confirmed to Fit:
Hobbyking 2804-210Kv
Hobbyking 2206-140Kv
Rctimer GBM2804
Might Fit:
Quanum 2208
DYS BGM2208

Controller:
Any 3 axis brushless gimbal controller to externally control the gimbal. I recommend a Storm32 board.

Weight:
Approximately 250g with camera, 175g without

Range of Motion
Pitch: -90 +90
Roll: -45 +45
Yaw: Depends on wiring

Balancing:

Balancing on the roll and yaw axes is done through loosening the bolts holding the arms to the roll/yaw motors and sliding the bolt spacer along the adjustment slot. For the pitch axis a similar thing is done with the pitch adjuster to adjust up and down. To adjust the pitch axis back and forth, shift the Session forward or back before tightening down the camera bar.

Different Motors/Parts:

If you need the design modified to fit a different gimbal motor or part, then let me know! I can modify the design for your needs. No guarantees though as there is only so much you can do without the physical parts in hand.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Print the bolt spacers, camera bar, camera clip, and pitch adjuster at 0.1mm.
The rest of the parts I recommend to print at 0.2mm.

Glueing:
To facilitate a printer friendly design, some parts have to be glued together. Super glue (CA) works best.

Glue the two halves of the tube hooks together. A brad inserted in between will add extra strength and help line up the pieces.

Glue the tube hooks to the lower isolator plate.

Glue the camera clip to the pitch adjuster.

title: Chevy Volt (2017) X Galaxy S8 phone mount

description.text:
This is a phone mount for the 2017 Chevrolet volt plug in EV. It's printed in two parts and can be glued with any suitable phone holder; I've included one for my phone, the Xiaomi Mi5.

It's mounted on the driver side accessories bay column. It's roughly hand drawn, so the fit is not perfect around the column. The fit for the phone, and USB-C cable, is perfect (use the included Xiaomi USB-C cable.

A great accessory for using android auto, phone slides right in. M3 hardware may need to be pressed in, depending on printer tolerances.

Highly recommend printing in ABS or PETG, something with a little flex and won't warp too easily on a hot summer day.

Required:

  • 2x M3 hex nut
  • 2x M3x12 screw
  • Xiaomi USB-C cable (or very similar)
  • screwdriver

Assembly is self explanatory, see pictures. Tighten down the screws to your liking. Slide USB-C cable in. Enjoy Android auto.

Notes:

The fit isn't perfect so use a more flexible filament like ABS or PETG and tighten down the nuts a little bit. PLA will warp in a hot car.

Use a tiny bit of support on bed only for the USB-C insert.

title: 80x20 aluminum exrtrusion Y-axis for Prusa type printers (Tronxy/Anet/Zonestar/Folgertech)

description.text:
I wanted to redo the y-axis on my Tronxy P802MA for lower noise and better overall quality. There are many way to go, but I chose wheel just to try. I already had a very good experience after converting X-axis to 20x20 extrusion with minigantry.

So, I found https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1278055
But the problem with that design that I wanted to leave my 16 tooth pulley because table is heavy and 20 tooth pulley would reduce holding power by 25-30%. Not good. Resolution is also a little concern, but not the primary one.
So, I did my version where belt goes inside v groove and strictly parallel to the axis. The most difficult part was to design a good belt holder while keeping it inside v-groove and parallel at all points.
I have finished the convertion. Printed test 20x20 cube, the size on x and y match to 2/100th of a millimeter. The noise reduction is huge.
However, I noticed that the motor and the idler add considerable length to y-axis, while I want everything to be compact. Since I plan to fully rebuild printer to aluminum extrusion I consider this conversion a temporary step just to test wheel operation on vslot. For the next version I will plan to put motor and idler under the extrusion, so, they will not add any length to the axis.
Because it is a temporary solution I did not design a low profile mount to the base for the axis. I just did two clip-on mount for my tronxy p802 which clip onto the acrylic frame (front and back parts). For your printer you would need to find solution for yourself.
BOM:
16 5x10 screws
4 5x20 screws (for table mount)
Full gantry for 80x20 extrusion with wheel (see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1278055)
10 t-nuts
5mm nuts
25mm 3mm screw, nuts (for tentioner, see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1285301)
Two small screws (2-3 mm, depends on end switch) for end switch mount.
Washers, etc.

PRINTED PARTS
See images on how to position then when printing.
Everything is printed with 0.25mm layer. I used 0.6mm nozzle to speed things up. 3 shells.
gantryhook-v3 - a belt hook, actually like crocodile jaw. Space is very limited, the jaw is too thin. After placing the belt between the teeth knot the jaw with some reliable material. I used thin fish line. Do it very tightly. Use someone’s help to hold the knot while you do the second knot. Print to the side so the teeth a very good quality, not supports. 100% infill. No support.

y-belt-tentioner – idler part. Supports are needed. 40% infill.
y-motor-holder – motor holder. Supports are needed. 40% infill.
y-mount – clip on for the axis to acrylic frame. Supports are needed. 40% infill. In shown orientation the top part (where extrusion is mounted) is flattest. When assembling the axis put this part with crews and t-nuts on the extrusion, clip the axis on the frame then remove the frame and tighten the screws. It is a mess, I know.
y-tablespacer – it is a spacer between gantry and table holder.

Notes on table
I use the original aluminum table from my tronxy as a table holder. And the table itself is fully glass now, I don’t use any aluminum under the glass. I have been using such setup since june 2017 and never had a problem. I will post this conversion later separately.

Models

All models are also provided in SolidWorks format. Feel free to play around, but add a remix to my thing if you post what you did.

description.text:
I had a feeling that I wanted my Z-Axis brackets to be a bit beefier so I added some height to daneelgs design. Please ignore the expertly taped (ahem) cable connection in the pics.
The left bracket with the cable chain mount can not be printed upside down, so I printed with some light supports touching build plate in order for the bridges to come out really smooth. Might have worked without though, but I didn't have a proper print cooling system installed at that time and did not want to risk it.
Be really careful when adding the cable chain, one side of my mounting pieces broke and I had to glue it back on (too impatient to wait for another print).

For 5mm (plywood) frame, I heard there's also 6mm out there so mind your printer's frame thickness.

This is my very first "own" creation here on thingiverse, so be kind :-)

title: Robo3D R1+ Cable Chain Kit (No Rewiring)

description.text:
A complete overhaul of the original to improve ease of printing, fit, and overall look. I went through over a dozen iterations just of the links to make them snap and hold together better. Carriage Bracket was smoothed considerably from the original file and shaved down to save weight while improving the looks a bit.

Print:

  • 19 No-Top Links
  • 19 No-Bottom Links
  • 1 Carriage Bracket
  • 1 End Mount
  • 1 Printhead Mount

I just attached the flat 'End Mount' to the R1 with some 3M VHB.

The 'Carriage Bracket' attaches and fits firmly with just the single screw removed and replaced on the Stepper Motor. There is a slot for a small zip-tie on the bracket where the cables feed through (This holds the wires so they don't cause things to come apart).

The 'Printhead Mount' is a bit longer with bigger "nubs" than the others to make it snap and hold together even better.

Robo 3D

R1 ABS + PLA Model

30

Notes:

Printing the links on a raft works best if you have a good printer/settings. My links popped off the raft very easily afterwards. You risk breaking the links if they get too well attached to the print surface directly.

***Only the 'Carriage Bracket' requires supports, everything else can be printed as-is w/ no supports.

I wanted to have an easy to reach switch to turn my printer on and off. Originally I made one that was intended to clip over the threaded rod but it didn't work all that well.
This redesign actually bolts onto the foot vertex and frame for support.

IMPORTANT
This Thing will mean playing with mains cables and voltages, that is between 110-240V depending on where you are. IT CAN AND WILL KILL. If you are unsure then contact an electrician for help. I take no responsibility for you deciding to do this! (butt covering out of the way...) Print the case and the lid. It is currently set for mounting on the left of the machine, but could be mirrored for right side mounting. The switch is a SPST rectangular rocker. Wire that to the live supply. Fit into case. Remove the two outer nuts on the vertex and push on the case. Replace the nuts. Screw lid on. Turn printer on and off easily!

I robbed two 80x20mm fan from a dead Thermaltake PC PSU. I thought that I'd repurpose one for my printer. This is my first remix and my first print was a little loose, but it held the fan just fine. This version is exactly 5mm shorter than the 25mm version by iziMakersand should fit perfectly. I hope this helps someone! So far this fan is silent (quieter than the extruder fan) and keeps my PSU nice and cool.

  • I shrank the Fan Holder by 5mm in SketchUp
  • The fan cover is unchanged

remixed_from.title: Playable Ukulele - Printable w/ no Supports

description.text:
Solstie's ukelele headstock that accepts metal guitar tuning machines.
I remixed it to fit onto the Makerlele_Mk1_Plus. This upgrade ruins the cool, entirely 3d printed aspect of the Makerlele, but it adds a great deal of playability. Metal tuning machines hold tune better than their 3d printed derivatives. Visit FreshPrints3D.com for more cool 3D printed stuff!

I printed mine with no top or bottom layers and ~30% honeycomb infill.
Raise the layer height to complete the print faster.
Use at least 4 walls/perimeters.

title: Anycubic I3 Mega Y Dual Extruder  conversion

description.text:
PLS Like !

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9PdE_59pAQM

Mit dieser Mod Firmware, welche auf Marlin basiert könnt ihr euren Anycubic I3 Mega auf Dual Extrusion via Y Verteiler mit nur einem Hotend umbauen.

Die Firmware ist nur mit der ersten i3 Version V1 und der zweiten V1.1 Ultrabase kompatibel! Die V1.4 wird nicht supported! Die 1.4 befindet sich auch nicht in meinem Besitz, somit kein Support.

!! Vorweg möchte ich noch sagen, ich übernehme keine Haftung/Verantwortung oder ähnliches.
Jeder ist für die Modifizierung seines Druckers selbst verantwortlich.

Wenn ihr von vornherein wisst, das ihr 2 Linke Hände habt, dann überlegt es euch 2 mal. Ich kann und werde nur begrenzt Support geben.

Meiner Meinung nach sollten folgende Grundvoraussetzungen vorhanden sein:

  • elektrisches Grund Know-how
  • Vorkenntnisse in Marlin
  • Sketch kompilieren/uploaden sollte bekannt sein
  • Eigeniniative! (gängige Suchmaschinen helfen:))

Hinweis!: Durch diese Firmware verliert die Ultrabase Version den linken Endschalter! dies lässt sich leider nicht vermeiden, da die 2 Z-Stepper Motoren danach parallel laufen und nur noch 1 Endschalter geschalten werden kann. (jeder Standard DIY Printer läuft mit nur einem Z-Endschalter ;))

Es wird benötigt:

  • 1x Nema17 Stepper 1,8Grad 1,5A
  • 1x Extrudersatz
  • 1x Ø1,75 Bowden Tube ca. 500 mm
  • 3x PC4-M6 pneumatische Schnellverbinder

Prinzipiell empfehle ich die Firmware individuell anzupassen! Die aktuelle ist nach meinen persönlichen Vorstellungen gestaltet.

Infos zum .hex File bzw. zu meiner generellen Anpassung:

Das Heatbed wird nicht mehr per BangBang gesteuert/geheitzt, sondern über PID! (die BedLED blinkt dadurch)
Der Autotune wird über M303 E-1 C10 S60 gestartet ( C=10 Intervalle, S60Grad)
gesetzt wird dann durch M304 Pxx Ixx Dxx und mit M500 speichern.

Linear Advance ist aktiviert, steht aber auf K0 R0 (falls gewünscht, Infos auf google)

Ich habe die Pins von Port Z2 auf E1 umbelegt um den zweiten Extruder benutzten zu können.

Der Z-Dual Stepperbetrieb wurde deaktiviert (ist notwendig)
Der Z-Dual Endstopbetrieb wurde deaktiviert (ist notwendig)

Steps/Acceleration sowie Jerk wurden an die originalen Werte angepasst.

Die Steps des E2 Extruders müssen auch eingestellt werden! (aktuell sind meine Werte hinterlegt).
Der Steps des zweiten Extruders können über M92 T1 E92.6 gesetzt werden. Mit M500 abspeichern.

Dies sind die gröbsten Änderungen.

Zum technischen Teil,

der zweite Z-Stepper der original auf E1 steckt, wird an den freien Z2 gesteckt. Der neue Stepper(Extruder2) wird an den E1 Port gesteckt (siehe Pinout Bilder).
Ich habe das Kabel durch die Schalteröffnung vorne Links geführt.
Den Extruder habe ich wie auf den Bildern links befestigt.

Nun druckt euch das Y-Stück liegend aus und schraubt 3x PC4-M6 Pneymatikschnellverbinder ein. In das V5 Hotend wird nun 1 Stück Teflonschlauch geschoben, welches unten bündig am Heatbreak ansteht. Oben sollte es soweit herausschauen dass das Y Stück mit samt Verbinder etwas Luft zwischen beiden Verbindern bildet. Die Schnellverbinder werden beide mit Kabelbinder gesichert (wie der Original Verbinder am Hotend)

Beide Extruder via Bowden Tube mit dem Y-Stück verbinden.

Für den Slicer kann ich euch nur mit Simplify3D helfen.

Die Problematik ist nun, Simplify braucht für einen Filamentwechsel bei dieser Länge
(Retract 150mm) ein Toolchange-Script.

Das Skript ist in Textform hinterlegt. Bis zur Funktion hat mich das gut 1,5 Tage gekostet ;)

Das Startscript muss auch eingefügt werden!

Diese Methode hat leider einen kleinen Haken, Simplify muss immer mit T0 starten. Dadurch müsst ihr natürlich je nach Teil die richtige Farbe im richtigen Extruder haben.

Die Skripte sind so ausgelegt, dass die Länge von Nozzle bis zum obersten Schnellverbinder um die 160 mm beträgt. Solltet ihr länger sein, müsst ihr das anpassen!

Ihr müsst außerdem ein neues Profil mit Dual Extruder anlegen. Ein Farb-Tower (Grundierungsstütze) mit ca 15mm muss eingestellt werden.

Wenn also alles erledigt ist, dann sieht der Ablauf wie folgt aus:

1 Extruder aufheizen!
2 T0 Material bis zum Schnellverbinder einfahren
3 T1 Material bis zum Schnellverbinder einfahren

4 Programm starten

5 Start Skript fährt T1 in die Noozle und wieder zurück.
6 Start Skript fährt T0 in die Noozle und bleibt.
7 T0 beginnt den Druck!

Nun sollte bei jedem Farbwechsel das Filament zurückgefahren werden und das neue auf dem Farb-Tower eingedruckt.

Also wer bis hier gelesen hat, der wird merken, ohne etwas Knowhow bzw. Liebe zum Hobby ist das ganze nicht zu empfehlen.

Wie schon gesagt, für mich ist es nicht möglich jedem immer und überall zu helfen.

Aber um das Prinzip verstanden zu haben, reicht es allemal :)

Auf die Arduino/Marlin Geschichte gehe ich nicht ein, diese Anforderung ist Grundvorassetzung. Wer da ohne wissen editiert, riskiert die Funktion seines Druckers.

Ich werde demnächst das Hotend komplett tauschen, um den Werkzeugwechsel Retract zu minimieren! Infos dazu folgen.

Für wen es hilfreich war, der darf gerne mal nen "TIP" (Spende) geben.

AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA

for now english google translator :) correct translation will follow

with this mod firmware, which is based on Marlin, you can convert your Anycubic I3 Mega to an Y Dual Extrusion with only one Hotend.

The firmware is only compatible with the first i3 version V1 and the second V1.1 Ultrabase! The V1.4 is not supported!

!! I would like to say in advance, I assume no liability / responsibility or similar.
Everyone is responsible for modifying their printer themselves.

If you know you have left hands, then think twice. I can and will only give limited support.

In my opinion, the following basic conditions should be present:

  • electrical reason know-how
  • previous knowledge in Marlin
  • compile / upload sketch should be known
  • own initiative! (common search engines help :))

Note !: With this firmware, the ultrabase version loses the left endstop! Unfortunately, this can not be avoided, because the 2 Z stepper motors run parallel. (every standard DIY Printer runs with only one Z endstop ;))

It is required:

  • 1x Nema17 Stepper 1,8degrees 1,5A
  • 1x extruder set
  • 1x Ø1.75 Bowden tube approx. 500 mm
  • 3x PC4-M6 pneumatic quick connectors

In principle, I recommend customizing the firmware! The current is designed according to my personal ideas.
Information about the .hex file or about my general adaptation:

The heatbed is no longer controlled by BangBang no with PID! (the BedLED will flash)
The autotune is started via M303 E-1 C10 S60 (C = 10 intervals, S60degrees)
set it by M304 Pxx Ixx Dxx and save with M500.

Linear Advance is activated, but is on K0 R0 (if you want, info on google)

I changed the pins from port Z2 to E1 to use the second extruder.

The Z-Dual stepper mode has been deactivated (is necessary)
The Z-dual endstop operation has been deactivated (is necessary)

steps / acceleration and Jerk have been adjusted to the original values.

The steps of the E2 extruder must also be set! (currently my values ​​are deposited).
The steps of the second extruder can be set via M92 T1 E92.6. Save with M500.

These are the changes.

To the technical part,

the second Z-Stepper, which is originally on E1, is put on the free Z2. The new stepper (extruder2) is plugged into the E1 port (see pinout pictures).
I pulled the cable through the switch opening on the front left.
I attached the extruder as shown in the pictures on the left.

Now print the Y-piece reclining and screw in 3x PC4-M6 pneumatic-connector. Put in a piece of bowden tube In the V5 hotend , which is below flush with the heatbreak. Above it should look out so far that the Y piece together with connector forms some air between the two connectors. The quick connectors are both secured with cable ties (like the original connector on the Hotend)

Connect both extruders to the Y-piece via bowden tube.

For the Slicer I can only help you with Simplify3D.

The problem is now, Simplify needs for a filament change at this length
(Retract 150mm) a toolchange script.

The script is in text form. I spent 1,5 days for this arrrrgh ;)

The start script must also be inserted!

Simplify always has to start with T0. Of course you have to put in the right color in the right extruder depending on the part.

The scripts are designed so that the length from Nozzle to the top quick connector is around 160 mm. If yours should be longer, you have to adjust that in the script!

You also need to create a new profile with dual extruders. A color tower (grounding support) with about 15mm must be set.

So if everything is done, then the process looks like this:

1 heat up extruder!
2 put in material up to the quick connector for T0
3 put in material up to the quick connector for T1

4 start the program

5 start script moves T1 to Noozle and back.
6 start script moves T0 into the Noozle and stays.
7 T0 starts printing!

Now, with each color change, the filament should be retracted and the new one printed on the color tower.

So who has read up to here, will remember, without some know-how or love for the hobby, the whole thing is impossible.

As I said before, for me it is not possible to help anyone anytime, anywhere.

but hope helps for understanding:)

I will not explain the Arduino / Marlin story, this requirement is a basic requirement. Those who edit without knowing risk the function of their printer.

I will replace the hotend completely in the near future to minimize the tool change retract! informations follow, stay prepared

For whom it was helpful, maybe do a "TIP" (donation).

title: Props for Lamborghini Gallardo Spyder rear lid struts

description.text:
The large props snap onto the hydraulic struts (rod diameter 10mm) of the rear lid, to hold them at full extension. They are useful when working on the engine for a prolonged period - a day or two - otherwise the hydraulic struts (part of the electric soft top mechanism) lose pressure and sag.

The orange colour imitates the Lamborghini part supplied with the car, which had gone missing.

The lid also has two gas struts and one of these (on the left side of the car) has a prop built in, but the lid still tends to sag on the right side. Therefore I have made a small prop that fits onto the gas strut (rod diameter 8mm) on the right side of the car (shown in yellow in my example photo).

Printer:

Anycubic Kossell Delta

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 layer height

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Although the 226mm height is well within my delta printer's capabilities, bed adhesion is a real challenge. Eventually I succeeded after cleaning the print platform and printing at 50mm/s. I wanted to design supports into the STL but couldn't figure out how, so I added a brim in Cura of 20 lines, and that did the trick.

Material is eSun Red PLA.

I used DesignSpark Mechanical from RS - my first-ever project! In 2D Sketch View, I created the shapes (lines and a circle), then trimmed away unnecessary lines, and extruded (pulled) the face. The files include the design saved before pulling, so that you can change the circle diameter etc. and pull again. I couldn't find how to alter the dimensions after pulling.

title: Raspberry Pi Laptop with Official Raspberry Pi Foundation 7" Touchscreen *Just 5 Parts!*  *Source files included*

description.text:
I would like to present my Raspberry Pi Laptop meant to use the official Raspberry Pi Foundation 7" multi point touch screen.

This has been designed in Solidworks 2017. The one thing I copied was the keyboard layout from www.thingiverse.com/thing:2753563

To build this exactly as I have here's the BOM:

  • Raspberry Pi 3 https://www.adafruit.com/product/3055
  • Pi Foundation Screen https://www.adafruit.com/product/2718
  • Powerbank https://goo.gl/VeZjqa
  • Keyboard https://goo.gl/mjzdm6
  • Micro USB Breakout https://goo.gl/AY9WF2
  • Speakers https://goo.gl/TLjGqa
  • Amplifier https://goo.gl/LHnBSk
  • 5 x M3.12 PlastiteScrews https://goo.gl/6QszPZ
  • 2 x M4x45 Screws https://goo.gl/bUcg5i
  • 4 x M3x8 Screws https://goo.gl/ysFPtd
  • 2 x M4 Nyloc Nuts https://goo.gl/KoAT2t
  • Dual USB Panel Mount https://goo.gl/2CBpgJ
  • Single USB Panel Mount https://goo.gl/pGCNpZ
  • 2x 4x1.5mm O-rings https://goo.gl/XX7cJv
  • Material of your choice!
  • A .2mm nozzle (I'll explain below)

Little bit expensive to make but these are parts I had so gonna use them. I designed this to screw together and to be as few prints as possible. It has a lot of room in it and should be pretty easy to assemble.

Take a look at the exploded diagram to see how it assembles.

For printing I ran everything with a .4 nozzle except the power button and palm rest. These I ran at the same time with a .2mm nozzle due to how tiny the spaces between the keys are. This did not take too much extra time since I kept that part as small as I could. I ran 1.2mm walls and 15% fill on the whole thing. No need for it to be heavy really.

Wiring to come! [It's still printing]

Source files included! Remix, customize and enjoy!

Thank you!

  • Update 3/8/2018 Updated base, made it 2mm taller inside. Needed a tiny bit more room. Also added front air vents to keep things cool. All files updated.

  • Update 3/8/2018.2 Updated again, moved the SD card slot down a bit. Got it all wired and working! Done, complete, enjoy!

print_settings.Notes:: Effector needs supports for the hot end mounting part.

title: 'The End' Effector
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my view on a delta end effector and matching carriages. I use them on a Kossel XL with 245mm diameter build area. They are designed to be used with Haydn's Carbon Fiber Arms and E3D v6. Arm spacing is 60mm to improve stability. Design goal was to raise the hot end mount higher in order to maximize the build volume.

There's a place for two 30mm axial fans on the effector for part cooling. Cooling shrouds are included, but they are untested, most likely less than ideal design and may be too high (reaching below nozzle tip plane). However, the cooling shrouds are not an absolute must IMO, print them and test them if you like.

You need two pieces of the E3D v6 mounts, might be good to use something more heat resistant than PLA for those e.g. ABS or PET-G, other parts should be ok in PLA. The standard 30mm E3D v6 cooler shroud with 30mm fan can be used if leaving out the two lower fan screws or slightly modify the effector to make all four screws fit.

The carriages have 20x20mm mount hole pitch for M3 bolts, compatible with e.g. MGN12 linear guide rail sleds. The carriages have no belt tightness adjustment as I use separate adjusters.

Please note that most of the parts need to be rotated before slicing to appropriate printing orientation.

Printer:

Kossel XL

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

up to 0.32mm layers with 0.4mm nozzle

Infill:
