author: Giman

title: Sonoff basic wallbox enclosure with decora faceplate

description.text:
This is a 3 parts enclosure for the Sonoff Basic that fits nicely in a typical electrical box.

This is a work in progress and I intend to make many versions of the top cover to accommodate different configurations (sensors, LED, buttons, switch, etc).

The middle part let the headers (that you added) out, so you can connect what you want.

All the parts snap together nicely.

The first top cover here can accommodate a 16mm button with LED ring.

Demo:
https://youtu.be/v5jVnbhwBvI

Demo installed in wall:
https://youtu.be/PuWODA1tGG0

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

25

Notes:

For the top cover I use 50% support density so that the wings print properly.
For the middle section, just use 15% support density
No need for supports for the bottom part.

Connecting the LED button

To connect the button

  1. Bridge the negative pin of the LED and the common pin of the switch.
  2. Solder the ground wire to the pins you've bridge in step 1. Cover with heat shrink
  3. Solder the the button wire to the NO pin. Cover with heat shrink
  4. Solder the LED wire to the positive pin of the LED. Cover with heat shrink.
  5. Connect the wires to the headers:
    • Ground wire to the 2nd farthest header pin from the embedded button (GND)
    • Button wire to the farthest header pin from the embedded button (GPIO14)
    • LED wire to the middle header pin (TX pin)
button connections Flashing the Sonoff

Use the Tasmota firmware to be able to use the button and the LED. There are a lots of video and web pages describing the process of flashing the Sonoff.

Before flashing the firmware, don't forget to configure your wifi settings. Additionally you will need to edit the "sonoff_template.h" file and change these two lines. This will enable the possibility to reallocate the function of the embedded LED and button to the one you plugged in instead.

GPIO_KEY1, // GPIO00 Button
to
GPIO_USER, // GPIO00 Button

GPIO_LED1_INV, // GPIO13 Green Led (0 = On, 1 = Off)
to
GPIO_USER, // GPIO13 Green Led (0 = On, 1 = Off)

Tasmota/Sonoff configuration

In the Tasmota/Sonoff web interface go in "Configure Module" and set

  • GPIO14 Sensor to "13 Button1"
  • GPIO1 Serial Out to "48 Led1"

title: TBS Crossfire Protector + Taranis Q X7 Stand - no screws - no supports
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Just bought a Crossfire and didn't find the existing protectors/stands to my taste. Printing them was too much of a hassle and using screws with 3D printed parts has rarely worked out for me. What's more, I'm not sure the other stands fit my Q X7 since they were made for the X9D.

So I redesigned the whole thing, taking care of making everything printable without supports and assemble without screws! The parts snap fit together, and the logo can be glued into the hole for added safety. The two legs snap onto the metal bar of the Taranis, you might need to give it a good push but this prevents the hooks from accidentally coming out.

Super happy with how it came out! I'm not sure the tolerances will work out for you the same it did for me so don't hesitate to let me know if it doesn't work for you in the comments!

You can also find the public OnShape document here for modifications.

description.text:
How do you like my coffee table? :-) Print 4 legs, get a suitable piece of wood and you can have one too! In the process you will become King of Retract!

It's about 200mm tall because that is the limit of my printer in z-direction. If yours is bigger, you could scale it a little taller! I glued mine to the table board with double sided tape, but there are 4 through-holes included in the design if you want to screw the legs on instead.

I printed this in black PETG (shiny!), but it should work great in any reasonably stiff material (e.g. ABS/PLA/...). If you have time you can make it super pretty and print at 0.1 mm layer height, but mine is 0.25 mm and still took around 11 hours per leg with a 0.35mm nozzle at 25% infill. Use a brim if necessary to help with bed adhesion, depending on your printer setup.

A great place to put things! Max load I have tested was about 15 kg.
Cheers!

description.text:
Gear Knob I designed for my R34 Skyline. Very Basic, but if you are good at mods in CAD I have included the original files, to add logo's etc as you please. If used to be sold, please give credit. If you need to design a bottom piece to look nicer, you can add a few holes for neodymium magnets into it, so the bottom is self attaching and easy to remove.

"EDIT"

Got around to cleaning up the original a bit for quicker prints. Print the lower at 100% infill and 3 perimeters Print the Gearstick Knob at 80% infill and 5 perimeters. Knob will need supports for the hex nut cutout and a brim of 30 perimeters with a zero offset to ensure it stays stuck, while having the bed at 60 to ensure the bottom doesn't melt. Knob prints ok at 0.2mm layers for the whole thing, but for best results, the first half can be done at 0.2mm layers up to 22mm high, then 0.12mm layers to 42mm high, then 0.08mm layers to finish. It will take around 8 to 10 hours at 50 to 60mm a second.

The lower has a 12mm hole which you can make bigger or smaller depending on your requirements. The 1mm Hex nut cutout will need supports, but can work without them. No brim needed on the lower.

The knob feels great in use, and the texture on the top which is a bit rougher than the bottom gives you good control for gear changes. It lowered my total gear-stick height by about an inch and feels like a short shifter now.

The hole in the base of the knob for the shaft is 9mm wide to allow you to add a thread for a 10mm shaft and even without a correct sized nut for your shaft, it should still hold if you just thread it onto the shaft, but if you have a nut that fits your gear stick shaft, you are guaranteed a solid fit. The nut cutout is 14mm from hex corner to opposite corner. Adjust if needed in 123D Design. Files included.

Logo of the brand new ferrari f1 challenger 2018

Headphone hanger using a lever to accommodate different desk thicknesses (~15-45mm). Turn the nut to adjust the arm and secure the hanger on your mounting surface. Only the body and arm pieces should require supports.

Insert the staticthread pieces into nut, pointing the same direction. Make sure nut is secured between the lugs. From the other side, thread in movingthread and movingthread2. One side of the thread assembly is held in the outer body slot by a pin (might need some light sanding at the beveled edge), the other in arm by a pin2 (again, some sanding might be necessary). The inner body slot holds the link, also with a pin, and also attached to arm with a pin2. At the far end of arm, pad is secured with a pin2.

In total you'll need 2 pins, 2 staticthreads, 3 pin2s, and 1 of everything else.

title: Tronxy X1 Horizontal Spool Stand on Original Handle

description.text: For those who need a horizontal spool holder that snaps on easily on top of the original Tronxy X1 handle without having to remove the handle. The is a remix from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:508896. The main thing I did was to design a cap piece that snaps onto the original handle at the top. I gave a bit more tolerance so that removal is easier, but the stand is quite stable and works well. I also adapted the spool holder base from thing:508896 by adding a pair of hex-nut recesses, and a M3 compatible holes. This enables the use of two of the original M3 20mm screws left from the installation pack to secure the spool holder base to the snap cap support that I designed. Four positions are possible to allow situating the guide-tube holder at a good position for the filament feed. Easy assembly and removal. If you require other options for the centring nut, spool spindle or guide-tube holder, please refer to thing:508896.

title: Nixie Tube Clock IN-1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Designed for IN-1 nixie tubes this clock case has room for 6 nixie tubes showing from top to bottom Hours - Minutes and Seconds. The PCB (kit) used in this build can be found in a link below. Behind the nixie clock 'tower' there is a box storing the pcb and giving the tall nixie case a sturdy base. I use a small 2 way toggle switch for the power on-off and a metal socket for the PSU in (Power supply Unit) i will also place these links to Ebay below.

The nice thing about in-1 tubes is that the base is made from 'Bakelite' a really nice and old material giving it a 'heavy duty' feel and they are dirt cheap! 6pcs in-1 tubes sell for €12/14$ including shipping to Europe.

(the clock next to it are in-14 tubes)

I did solder the wires directly onto the back pins of the tubes but you can also use 4mm female PSU Molex pins found in PC hardware. Some small parts and hardware you also need are 8 3x15 screws and a 9v 500mah PSU.

Building Tips

Its the best to use PLA as material and CA glue to glue all the parts together. I use Matte A4 photo paper to cover all the printed parts to give it a smooth surface and a good base for the paint. You can use Bison tix/kit (rubber cement) to stick the paper to the pla parts giving it a good bond. After this you must use primer any cheap spray can primer will do, because of the paper a lot of primer will be absorbed so use 2 coats before painting it. Don't use glossy photo paper most paints will not stick to it...

print_settings.Notes:: Take care with the corners lifting up. Slight lift-up is ok, the corner will still work as normal.

description.text: This is a corner for a picture framing clamp. The print turns a standard 25mm tie-down strap into a picture framing tool.

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

medium

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Take care with the corners lifting up. Slight lift-up is ok, the corner will still work as normal.

Assembly of two corner halves

To make a complete picture framing set, you will need to print this model eight times. Each corner is assembled from two identical halves and two 10mm dowels. I used superglue to stick the two halves together. The steps I use to assemble:

  1. Drill through the dowel holes with a 9.5mm drill bit to remove print debris
  2. Cut two dowels to a length so they are SHORTER than the two halves put together (so it can be clamped properly)
  3. Insert the dowels partially into one of the halves
  4. Apply superglue on all mating surfaces
  5. Press together briefly, then quickly lay down on a flat surface and hammer the dowels completely into the complete corner
  6. Insert corner into a bench vice and tighten (hard) and leave it for an hour (while you print the next two halves)

Made on Earth by humans

and I used Fusion 360

description.text:
This is a painting handle capable of holding miniatures with bases of 25mm as well as 32mm in diameter but not limited to this. The handle makes it much more easier to hold a miniature during painting. It contains 2 different slots for bases of different diameter. There is also a slot on the bottom where you could glue in a 10x1 magnet in order to stick it to some metallic surface (can lids?).

UPDATE 10 March 2018:

  • Added 0.2mm chamfer to the handle to prevent formation of 'elephant foot'

UPDATE 5 March 2018:

  • gap between Handle and Platform increased from 0.2 to 0.3 mm
  • chamfers added to the Cap

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Before printing make sure you've rotated all the pieces as shown on the image.

Support is needed for caps only. All other pieces are designed to be printed without support.

Print

  • 2x Caps
  • 2x Platform
  • 1x Handle

To assemble the handle you would need a rubber band and a paper clip.

  1. make a hook out of paper clip.
  2. coil rubber band twice or three times (I found 3x works better but definitely harder to assemble)
  3. seize coiled rubber band with the hook on one cap
  4. assemble handle and 2 platforms and pass paperclip hook through holes in them
  5. grab the rubber band and pull out the hook
  6. use something to fix the rubber band from another side and put the second cap on

Enjoy!

description.text:
I created a license plate bracket for a 2017 KTM XCW 300 dirt bike.

While I didn't want to have to drill holes in the bike's fender, I decided it was the best way to mount this bracket. I wanted the bolts that hold the bracket to the bike to go through the plate as well. This way, if the bracket breaks during a ride, I don't loose the plate in the woods. THIS REQUIRES HOLES TO BE DRILLED IN THE BIKE FENDER AND THE PLATE.

There are also mount holes for the edges of the plate to hold it flush. This prevents the plate from becoming a "razor blade" if it gets bent up.

I recommend using washers for all mounting hardware.

NOTE: The picture above shows the first version. The version uploaded has been corrected so holes are lined up and margin around plate is even.

A Simple hoof pick for the horses.

The photo is from an earlier version with bigger pike. In this version I have reduced the size and hope it is more practical.
Originally the design was build for a workmate of me and an ill horse. She looked for a thing like a "hoof pick" to remove food debris from the mouth of the horse, therefore I initially designed the pike more blunt.
I hope the hoof pick will also be practical for someone as a normal hoof pick. Feel free to give some comments for optimizations and I will try to fix it.

description.text:
i made this Compressed Air turbine because there was nothing on thingiverse that looked like what i wanted.
so here is what your are gonna need to assembly it;

  • 5 M3x30 bolts
  • 1 3mm thick and 3cm long nail
  • a few M3 washers
  • strong glue

so here is how it should be assembled:
insert the nail through the hole on the bottom of the turbo housing and secure it in to place with glue. make sure it is alligned properly and it's pointing upwards.also put some M3 washers over the nail before you insert the impeller over the nail and secure the upperplate with the M3x30 bolts.

if you want to hook it up to a compressor you could tap a M8 fitting into the side hole of the turbine.

note: i'm not responsible for any ijuries caused by this thing. building this and experimenting with this thing is at your own risk.

have fun with it and don't let it blow up in your face!

Huib

author: stmorgan

title: Cooling Fan Shroud for Creality Ender-2

description.text:
What the world needs is yet another cooling fan shroud for the Creality Ender-2. Not really but it does need one that works. I say that because at least two of the more popular designs have an interference with the lower X-Axis axle bolt. I tried a number of others and did not find anything that I deemed suitable but then I have sort of a warped idea of what is acceptable. So I did a new design in BricsCAD. The goals were:

1) No points of interference
2) No printing supports required
3) Symmetrical (consistency and symmetry are next to godliness)
4) Use standard sized 40 x 10 mm cooling fan
5) Be able to see the print nozzle
6) Withstand at least 230 degrees print temperatures without damage
7) Usable when printed in standard PLA

What I have come up with is made of two parts solvent welded together. The final version is the result of numerous trial and errors. The design that I am posting has run nozzle heat at 240 degrees with no detectable damage. I have used this fan shround on the Ender-2 to print PLA, FlexPLA and ABS. While it is usable when printed in PLA, I recommend using a higher temperature filament like ABS.

I realize a number of people use some form of Cyanoacrylate such as superglue but these do not work as well as solvent based adhesives and they have a short shelf life. I used SCIGrip #16 but others such as WeldOn or Testors part No 3509C should work just as well. I also recommend lightly sanding the bottom surface of the assembled fan shroud with 400 grit wet sand paper. Be careful ... that is a very thin wall.

I have also included a two part cover for the fan just to prove how anal retentive I can be. I printed this cover with Parmount’s FlexPLA with the idea that it might make my Mini-Kaze SY124010L fan a bit quieter. It is not any quieter but I like the aesthetics. With the fan cover all six of the required fasteners are M3 x 16mm.

My major problem in starting this project was in getting some basic dimension of the hot end. Thus the first thing that I had to draw was the Creality Ender-2 Mk8 hot end. For those of you that might be interested I have also included that drawing. For those that might want to “mess with perfection” (did I actually say that ?) I have include the original DXF model files as well.

All of the referenced files are the exclusive work product of the author and placed into the Public Domain by the author 22 February 2018 without any warranty expressed or implied.

description.text:
I needed a simple model of a Titan extruder with an E3D v6 plus Volcano heater block, and I wasn't able to find one around (possibly my search-fu failed me). As Taxilian and Professional3D had good Titan and V6 Volcano models respectively, I mashed the 2 together in tinkercad.

title: OpenRC Truggy Central Torsen Limited Slip Differential

description.text:
Managed to model Torsen Limited Slip Differential small enough to fit Truggy with only few parts requiring to change. Those will be: Central Diff Cases and Top Decks and Diff itself of course :) N24 D12, N16 D16 and N8 D8 parts printed at 0.1mm, other at 0.2mm. For central diff I used PETG. Didn't managed to capture outdoor run, but it runs brutally :) I could claim that there is a difference between open diff and torsen. One issue tho, sometimes having issues with turn radius. Overall I'm happy with result. Now it way easier to control it in straight line with full speed on slippy road while with open diff I only just spin out constantly.
After 5min of torture, broke front diff, but Truggy still runs with rear wheels because central diff is LSD :)
UPDATE: for pins I bought 3mm diameter nails from local depo and cut them to 23mm lenght.

This is a fun project to recreate the 1973
Emerson, Lake & Palmer, 'Brain Salad Surgery' album cover as a sculpture.

There are 7 different pieces to it, some are multiple prints and some need to be printed and then mirrored.

Some 10mm screwed rod, 6mm plain rod, some flexible conduit and of course a stylised skull are also required.

The pieces need to be glued together and given a 'distressed' look. (Paint and filler).

Be warned though the project requires a LOT of printing

Anet A6

I used PLA
200 extruder, 50 Bed
70mm/sec, 20mm/sec initial layer
5mm retract, at 50mm/sec
Fill density 20%

Hi, printing big organizers sucks, and the commercially available ones are maybe too pricy for you.

This solved the issue for me, because i was able to put this together under 10$

I used an 8mm diameter steel rod, resealable bags, two angled pieces of steel and a bit of hotglue.

Basic functionality: fill the bag with whatever, close it, slide on the clip, hang the bag and done.

It's less convenient than drawers in terms of speed, but that's what i'm willing to give up.

I printed these with the hook on bed and i used brim and supports. So it was kinda hard sanding all 50 of them. If you could somehow avoid the brim you would be saving yourself some time on that.

comments.author: djsunair

description.text:
This is an original .stl file, representing a 28mm model of the Trubia Naval Tank, which was manufactured and used in the Spanish Civil War. Please note this the the "Naval" version, not the earlier Trubia A4, which shares its name but little else. A review of this tank is in this link:
http://www.tanks-encyclopedia.com/ww2/spain/Trubia_naval.php
There are commercial models of this tank available, but they have what to me some design errors; e.g. they have the turret MG mounted centrally, yet in actual photos and design plans (attached) you see the MG is offset to the right, which makes sense when you consider just how small and cramped this tank was- look at the photos with men standing next to it. Its crew of three would have been quite tightly squeezed. The tracks may look odd; there is not evident room for suspension movement - that is because there was no suspension! The ride would have been brutally rough.
Nonetheless, the tank was built and used. The definition of the print will come out with painting, washes and dry brushing; there are defined vents and louvers etc. There are evident variances in photos; some without the side doors; some with angled doors and others with the rectangular doors; I went with the last.
The Spanish Civil War is too seldom considered topic, both for its deep history and great opportunity to represent in 28mm gaming. I hope this may encourage others to explore both.

description.text:
This was a holder I made for my Craftsman hex keys that were just loose in a bag. There's a little nub in each hole to create a little friction with the wrench. For me at least, the smaller the key, the tighter they fit. They all stay in place when you turn it upside down but the larger ones aren't as tight.

The letters came in pretty good for 0.3 mm layer height too, so I don't think a smaller resolution is needed.

This may not have all the right long/short holders that you need for your set. If you like this but want a slightly different arrangement of keys, message me and if it's easy enough, I can tweak the model for the arrangement of keys you need.

author: Berwing

description.text:
Please, read and understand everything before you do anything.

Skills needed: hand cutting and hand drilling aluminum, basic soldering, basic gluing.

I was very tired of how uneven aluminum plates was. Cast and cnc-ed aluminum is very expensive and hard to find. Also, since my printed has a moving bed, I am always finght the bed weight. Most people use aluminum and then put glass on top. Too heavy. Some just use heater plate as a base and clamp glass on top. Okay for not moving bed, but too flimsy for a moving one.
So, I though why I need the aluminum bed at all? Just for the screws? Then let’s find way to screw the glass the carriage and not even damage the top side of the glass.
Usual window glass is no good. Maybe even maybe not. So, I tested the method on usual glass and then used a 4 mm mirror. Mirror is good because it can be visually controlled for any distortion. Eye is very sensitive instrument, can see holes up to 0.01mm and detect very small distortions.
Using a mirror, I also increased the printable area to 230x230 mm.
Tasks list
1) Cut mirror
2) Attach heater
3) Attach screws

Cutting mirror
Very easy. Just use hand glass cutter of any time. Then use 150-200 grid sand paper to clean the edge. Easy.
Attaching the heater
Complex tax. Need to make cut outs for the screws and glue and resolder connection. Nothing too difficult, basic soldering skills. The problem here is that I used my original aluminum table as a carriage, so the whole are still like for 214x214, the same whole distances in the heater. Also, I wanted to make 3 screws attachment, not 4. So, I made all cutout, resoldered with thick wire. Next I used thin layer of thermal compound in some pattern (see photos) and then silicon glue (pure silicon, hold up to 250C and conducts heat a lot better than air). Then I attached the mirror and heater together and put 5kg load on top for 3 days. Done.
Attaching screws.
Worst part. Took me some experiments to choose the right glue and the gluing method. The glue must be hard enough to avoid any detectable movement during direction change, but elastic enough to withstand some thermal and mechanical deformations. Also, must withstand temperature up to 100C. Must bind very good to metal and to glass.
Pure 2 component epoxy does not work well. It breaks of the glass and breaks too easily. Does not tolerate temperature change very well. Since I am in Russia I found local glue called TITAN 6
http://anles.ru/product/%D1%8D%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%BA%D1%81%D0%B8-%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD-%E2%84%966/
It is a epoxy rubber glue, which is hard enough and can work up to 120C. Amazing glue. Very strong. Use google translate and find something like that in your area.
But still, it does not hold very good to clean glass. Hold very strong to the screw head, but can be detached from glass with no so much force. However, even like that I printed for 4 month without problems.
But eventually I dropped the bed when I was changing two wheels and all screws detached from the glass. No problem. This time I took a glass drill (4mm) and made 6-7 indentation in each place about 1-2mm deep. And glues the screws back. Now the holding force is amazing. Just make sure you clean the indents very well.
When gluing you need to place the screws as precise as you can. For that I used my old table as a template. Out the screws into it with two nuts and tightened it on the screw end. So, screws was sitting tight in the template plate sticking out the head as much as possible. Before that I made a whole where a new screws possible will be (I used 2 old whole, and one new, because switched to 3 point attachment).
Place glass table upside down. Clean the gluing places with IPA. Wait for it to evaporate. Put some glue onto the places and push some into the indents with a toothpick. Then just place the template plate with screws on top of it. After about 30 minutes I used toothpick to bring some more glue from bottom onto the screw heads and even a little on the thread. After 24 hours it is ready to be used.
Assembly
I hate springs in the table assembly. It is always a problem. Everything must hold tight. So, My assembly (from top to bottom) on each screw is like this: Screw-nut-washer-carriage-washer-lockwasher-hand nut. See photo – you will understand.
If all three screws do not want to go into the wholes at the same time, then they were places not very straight. I solved this problem just by using 4mm metal drill to enlarge one whole in the table carriage base.

Results.
Since I do not print ABS I don’t need to head by bed to 100C. I tested it up to 80 about 10 cycles and it now heats a lot faster even without any heat insulation underneath. I checked it with a pyrometer. This is obviously due to better thermal connection between heater and the bed.
I used a lot of force when detaching some PETG models and even PLA with big bed surface and did not have any problems.
The bed is now extremely flat. Here is G29
At 25C:
0 -0.060 -0.085
1 -0.045 -0.045
At 50C:
0 -0.037 -0.055
1 -0.035 -0.035
As you see the height difference is within 0.03mm. With 0.2mm first layer gives perfect 1st layer.
As you see the heater does not cover full areas of the print bed. That’s ok. Full area only needed for rare cases and even using heater 40C will give me about 33C on the edge, so PLA attached better.
I also tried glass with PEI on top. It is more problems than advantages. Now I used just clean glass with some glue stick dissolved in water. Good for PLA, PETG, SBS.

Good luck.

title: PS4 thumbstick extenders - library of options

description.text:
I designed a PS4 joystick extender that would print with the detail I wanted. I had printed some other extenders I found on Thingiverse, but they wouldn't print with the detail I wanted. Either there was too much overhang or I'd print with supports but the final product didn't look great.

The ones I created print in 2 pieces and then I super glued the halves together. So yes, there's some post-processing, but doing so allows you to get good detail on the top of the stick (where your thumb goes) and good detail on the snapping features.

I created a whole library of options depending on what you may find comfortable - different heights and with or without ridges on top (for extra grip), etc. Choose a bottom (suffix "_bot") based on the height you want and a top (suffix "_top") based on the style of top you want. Here's the decoder for the file names:

The "2d" or "3d" is the depth (2 = 2 mm, 3 = 3mm) of the dent on top. The ones that have a 2 mm depth have an option for a convex bump or not (see below). The ones that have a 3 mm deep dent only have the convex bump on top.

The number before the h is the height in mm. So "10h" is a 10 mm height extension.

The "b" or "no-b" is whether of not there's a bump on top. Meaning, if it's "no-b," then the top is concave. If it's "b" then it's convex on top.

Lastly, the "r" and "no-r" is whether or not there are ridges on top. Personally, I don't use them on the ones I used, but I tried it out to see if I liked the extra grip from them.

The one shown in the images is a "3d_b_no-r" and a 10 mm height extension.

Printer:

XYZ da Vinci Jr. 1.0w

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

100

Notes:

I used 100% infill because the parts are small, so by the time you add shells/outer walls, there's not much room for infill anyway.

I used supports on the bottom part.

title: Anycubic i3 Mega - Holder for drag chain - Halter für Schleppkette

description.text:
Es gibt eine Vielzahl von Schleppketten, die sicherlich alle nicht schlecht sind!
Ich habe mich jedoch dazu entschlossen eine zu kaufen, da sie definitiv sauber läuft, sehr dünnwandig und zuverlässig ist. Was mir aber dazu gefehlt hat, ist eine entsprechende Halterung... darum habe ich mir Abhilfe geschaffen!
Jetzt wird sich der ein oder andere fragen, warum die Kette nach vorne verläuft und nicht nach hinten. Ja, wenn sie nach hinten läuft, besteht nicht die Gefahr, dass das Hotend evtl. in die Kette fährt, da sie "zu hoch" ist. Die gekaufte Kette liegt allerdings so tief, dass eine Zusammenstoß mit dem Hotend oder Teilen davon ausgeschlossen ist (bei mir jedenfalls).
Ich musste mich für die Ausführung der Kette nach vorne entschließen, da wenn sie nach hinten laufen, sie an die hintere Wand stoßen würde und ich keinen Platz habe, den Drucker weiter nach vorne zu stellen!
Ein großer Vorteil ist der, dass bei dem Wechsel der UltraBase nicht der komplette Drucker auseinander genommen werden muss! Mann schraubt einfach die UltraBase ab, klemmt sie ab, bereitet die neue entsprechend vor und klemmt diese an! Kein lästiges Friemeln mehr!
Um die Halterungen anzbringen muss nichts baulich am Drucker verändert werden! Die Halterungen werden einfach angeschraubt, bzw. unter dem Heatbed aufgeklickt... hält bombenfest!

Hier die gekaufte Kette bei Ebay:
https://www.ebay.de/itm/302450305447?ul_noapp=true

Printer:

ANYCUBIC i3 MEGA

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

1,5 mm

Infill:

20 %

Notes:

Man kann natürlich die Halterungen entsprechend modifizieren oder spiegelverkehrt drucken um die Schleppkette nach hinten zu führen!
Außerdem kann man auch die Halterung natürlich für jede andere beliebige gekaufte oder gedruckte Kette verwenden... dazu einfach etwas Anpassungen durchführen!

Man braucht eine Lüsterklemme, ein paar Kabelbinder, natürlich die Kette und Schrumpfschlauch (optianal) Ein Ende der Kette mir der Platte Druckergehäuse (unten plan) verkleben! Habe dazu 2-K-Kleber genommen... anderer geht natürlich auch! Das gleiche mit dem anderen Ende der Kette und der Klemme Heatbed gemacht! Die Platte Lüsterklemme auf die Klemme Heatbed kleben. Dazu ist sie so geformt, dass die Anbringung selbsterklärend ist! Ich musste das so lösen, da das alles in einem Guss zu drucken mit sehr viel Support verbunden gewesen wäre! Kabel einführen! An den Enden einen Schrumpfschlauch anbringen (optional) Am anderen Ende ebenfalls! Ende mit Kabelbinder fixieren! Kabel auf die richtige Länge zuschneiden, abisolieren und wenn möglich verlöten! Kabel an der Lüsterklemme anschließen! Das Kabel an der UtraBase auf die richtige Länge bringen, Schrumpfschlauch darüber (optional), abisolieren und wenn möglich die Enden verlöten! Kabel an die Lüsterklemme anschließen! Natürlich noch im inneren die Kabel entsprechend anklemmen... hatte leider vergessen Bilder davon zu machen!

Gearbox 256 /
Getriebe 256

I used the parts from "Gearset 1:2 ratio" to build a gearbox, but instead of designing a reduction system, i wanted to go a different way and increase the outgoing speed.
The idea was to create a hand driven box for various tasks which require fast rotation. It's also a test of how much you can increase the speed with 3D-printed gears.
As the rotation speed goes up, accuracy and friction become more important. In the attached video, the crank is rotated at 10 rpm while the driven shaft spins at 2,560 rpm.
In conclusion, the crank rotation needs a bit too much force. I've just started designing a complete new gearbox for easier usage.

/

Ich habe die Teile aus "Zahnradsatz 1:2 Übersetzung" verwendet um ein Getriebe zu bauen, aber anstatt ein Reduktionssystem zu konstruieren, wollte ich einen anderen Weg gehen
und die Ausgangsgeschwindigkeit erhöhen. Die Idee war, ein handbetriebenes Getriebe für verschiedene Aufgaben zu entwickeln, die eine schnelle Rotation benötigen.
Es ist auch ein Test wie hoch man die Geschwindigkeit mit zu 3D-gedruckten Zahnrädern erhöhen kann. Bei steigender Drehgeschwindigkeit werden Genauigkeit und Reibung immer
wichtiger. In dem angehängten Video wird die Kurbel mit etwa 10 u/min gedreht, während die angetriebene Welle mit 2.560 U/min rotiert. Zusammenfassend benötigt die Kurbel-Drehung
etwas zu viel Kraft. Ich habe gerade begonnen, ein komplett neues Getriebe für eine einfachere Nutzung zu entwickeln.

Parts/Teile

  1. Box/Gehäuse - 1 Piece/Stück
    182 x 63,7 x 80 mm

    • Insert in pockets/In Taschen einsetzen:
      2x Bearing/Lager 608 Z (7x8x22mm)
      2x Bearing/Lager 6901 Z (6x12x24mm)
      10x Nut/Mutter M5
      1x Part/Teil 8 - Bearing-disk/Lagerscheibe 1
      1x Part/Teil 19 - Bearing-disk/Lagerscheibe 2

  2. Top / Deckel - 1 Piece/Stück
    182 x 65,5 x 4 mm

    • Includes holes for 3.5 mm screws, but the top fits perfectly without them. / Enthält Bohrungen für 3,5 mm Schrauben, aber der Deckel hält auch ohne sehr gut.

  3. Shaft / Welle 1 - 1 Piece/Stück
    12 x 50 mm

    Part order / Reihenfolge der Teile

    a - Part/Teil 6 - Crank/Kurbel
    b - Part/Teil 7 - Spacer/Distanzstück 1
    c - Part/Teil 8 - Bearing-disk/Lagerscheibe 1
    d - Bearing/Lager 61901 ZZ (6x12x24mm)
    e - Part/Teil 9 - Clamp/Klemme 1
    f - Part/Teil 10 - Spur gear/Stirnrad 1
    g - Part/Teil 11 - Spacer/Distanzstück 2
    h - Bearing/Lager 61901 ZZ (6x12x24mm)

    The gear is rigidly connected to the shaft and spins with the crank rotation.
    This shaft transmits the biggest torque. Both parts must be printed more durable
    (4 perimeter, 4 solid top/bottom layers, infill 40%). The crank is glued to the outer
    end of the shaft.
    /
    Das Zahnrad ist starr mit der Welle verbunden und rotiert mit der Kurbeldrehung.
    Diese Welle überträgt das größte Drehmoment. Beide Teile müssen stabil gedruckt werden
    (4 Umrissbahnen, 4 Volle Boden- und Dachschichten, Füllung 40%). Die Kurbel ist mit dem
    äußeren Wellenende verklebt.

  4. Shaft / Welle 2 - 2 Piece/Stück
    8 x 54 mm

    Part order "shaft 4 gears" / Reihenfolge der Teile "Welle mit 4 Zahnrädern"

    a - Part/Teil 12 Spacer/Distanzstück 3
    b - Assembly Doublegear without Part/Teil 18 Spacer/Distanzstück 7
    c - Assembly Doublegear
    d - Assembly Doublegear
    e - Assembly Doublegear
    f - Part/Teil 13 - Spacer/Distanzstück 4
    g - Part/Teil 14 - Clamp/Klemme 2

    Part order "shaft 3 gears" / Reihenfolge der Teile "Welle mit 3 Zahnrädern"

    a - Part/Teil 15 Spacer/Distanzstück 5
    b - Assembly Doublegear without Part/Teil 18 Spacer/Distanzstück 7
    b - Assembly Doublegear
    c - Assembly Doublegear
    a - Part/Teil 16 - Spacer/Distanzstück 6
    e - Part/Teil 14 - Clamp/Klemme 2

    Assembly Doublegear - 7 Piece/Stück

    a - Part/Teil 17 - Double spur gear / Doppelstirnrad
    b - Bearing/Lager 608Z (7x8x22mm)
    c - Part/Teil 18 - Spacer/Distanzstück 7

    The gears are spinning freely on the shafts and transmit the torque.
    The shafts can be printed with standard settings.
    /
    Die Zahnräder drehen frei auf den Wellen und übertragen das Drehmoment.
    Die Wellen können mit Standardeinstellungen gedruckt werden.

  5. Shaft 3 / Welle 3 - 1 Piece/Stück
    8 x 62 mm

    Part order / Reihenfolge der Teile

    a - Part/Teil 19 - Bearing-disk/Lagerscheibe 2
    b - Bearing/Lager 608Z (7x8x22mm) outside/außen
    c - Part/Teil 20 - Spur gear/Stirnrad 2
    d - Part/Teil 14 - Clamp/Klemme 2
    e - Bearing/Lager 608Z (7x8x22mm) inside/innen

  6. Crank/Kurbel - 1 Piece/Stück
    181 x 34 x 10 mm

    Part order / Reihenfolge der Teile

    a - Bearing/Lager 61901 ZZ (6x12x24mm)
    b - Part/Teil 21 - Spacer handle bearing/Scheibe Grifflager
    c - Part/Teil 22 - Handle/Griff
    d - Part/Teil 9 - Clamp/Klemme 1
    e - Part/Teil 9 - Clamp/Klemme 1
    f - Part/Teil 9 - Clamp/Klemme 1
    g - Part/Teil 9 - Clamp/Klemme 1
    f - Part/Teil 9 - Clamp/Klemme 1

    The crank and the handle transmit a high bending moment. Both parts must be printed more durable
    (3 perimeter, 3 solid top/bottom layers, infill 30%). The "spacer handle bearing" is glued.
    /
    Die Kurbel und der Griff übertragen ein hohes Biegemoment. Beide Teile müssen stabil gedruckt werden
    (3 Umrissbahnen, 3 Volle Boden- und Dachschichten, Füllung 30%). Die "Scheibe am Grifflager" ist eingeklebt.

  7. Spacer/Distanzstück 1 - 1 Piece/Stück
    6.4 x 16 x 12 mm

  8. Bearing-disk/Lagerscheibe 1 - 1 Piece/Stück
    1 x 32 x 18 mm

  9. Clamp/Klemme 1 - 6 Piece/Stück
    10 x 20 x 12 mm

  10. Spur gear/Stirnrad 1 - 1 Piece/Stück

    Number of teeth / Zähnezahl: 30
    Pitch circle / Wälzkreisdurchmesser: 67.5 mm
    Hub diameter / Nabendurchmesser: 12 mm

  11. Spacer/Distanzstück 2 - 1 Piece/Stück
    2 x 16 x 12 mm

  12. Spacer/Distanzstück 3 - 1 Piece/Stück
    1,5 x 12 x 8 mm

  13. Spacer/Distanzstück 4 - 1 Piece/Stück
    2,25 x 12 x 8 mm

  14. Clamp/Klemme 2 - 3 Piece/Stück
    10 x 16 x 8 mm

  15. Spacer/Distanzstück 5 - 1 Piece/Stück
    6 x 12 x 8 mm

  16. Spacer/Distanzstück 6 - 1 Piece/Stück
    6,75 x 12 x 8 mm

  17. Double spur gear / Doppelstirnrad - 7 Piece/Stück

    Number of teeth / Zähnezahl: 15 and 30
    Pitch circle / Wälzkreisdurchmesser: 33.75 and 67.5 mm
    Hub diameter / Nabendurchmesser: 22 mm

  18. Spacer/Distanzstück 7 - 5 Piece/Stück
    2 x 12 x 8 mm

  19. Bearing-disk/Lagerscheibe 2 - 1 Piece/Stück
    1 x 29 x 18 mm

  20. Spur gear/Stirnrad 2 - 1 Piece/Stück

    Number of teeth/Zähnezahl: 15
    Pitch circle/Wälzkreisdurchmesser: 33.75 mm
    Hub diameter/Nabendurchmesser: 8 mm

  21. Spacer handle bearing/Scheibe Grifflager - 1 Piece/Stück
    2 x 29,5 x 21 mm

  22. Handle/Griff - 1 Piece/Stück
    12 x 58 mm

In order for the gears to work well together, the 3D printer should be
calibrated properly and produce clean external surfaces. If possible
aline the starting points of the outer perimeters and
remove the plastic bumps in a single cut.

The shafts are constructed without play. If the parts are not
plug into each other, STL files must be downsized in the radial direction.

Some parts includes a clamping function with nuts and grub screws. I noticed during the assembly,
that the clamping can be to implemented easier by variation of the parts dimensions.

After the assembly the gearbox might need some running time till the gears are working smoothly. Lubrication is very helpful.

/

Damit die Zahnräder gut miteinander arbeiten sollte der 3D-Drucker korrekt
kalibriert sein und saubere Außenflächen produzieren. Nach Möglichkeit setzt
man den Startpunkt der äußeren Bahnen übereinander um die dortige
Kunststoffanhäufung mit einem Schnitt entfernen zu können.

Die Wellen sind ohne Spiel konstruiert. Falls sich die Teile nicht
ineinander stecken lassen, müssen STL-Dateien in radialer Richtung
verkleinert werden.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a Reamersharpeningattachment for a D-Bitgrinder.
The Problem was that i couldn´t change the teeth because the settingfinger couldn´t exit the space between two teeth.
You won´t be able to grind reamers in the Dividinghead because the teeth aren´t divided as you would expect. Therefore you use the settingfinger.
My Spacer allows you to grind each tooth on a defined setting, but you can swing it away for changing the tooth by allowing the settingfinger to pass by.

See the pictures for forther information!
Sorry, no D-Bitgrinder, no sharp reamers!

Lower axis 5°, upper axis 45° for machinereamers.
I have no experience with handremers, i thing this is not going to work fine!

Système de Leds à petit prix pour l'éclairage de votre Tevo Tornado ou Creality CR-10 :

Vous avez besoin de (Il existe une version 12 et 24v) : https://es.aliexpress.com/item/MOONBIFFY-1PCS-DC-24V-6-SMD-LED-Car-Bus-Truck-Trailer-Lorry-Side-Marker-Indicator-Light/32820272198.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.fveeSa

Pour pouvoir installer la pièce dans le V-Slot de la Tevo Tornado, vous devez retirer les vis du V-Slot coté droit. Exercez une légère flexion de la pièce support et tout en tenant la flexion faites la glisser lentement dans le V-Slot, puis relâcher.Vous pouvez ajouter un vis M3-M5 munie d'un T-nut.

Les leds sont branchées en parallèle (12-24v) directement sur l’alimentation (24v-12v pas 110-220v)

Pour que la pièce soit solide, je conseille 90% d'infill.

Low cost led lights in 12-24 v.

You need in (12 or 24v) : https://es.aliexpress.com/item/MOONBIFFY-1PCS-DC-24V-6-SMD-LED-Car-Bus-Truck-Trailer-Lorry-Side-Marker-Indicator-Light/32820272198.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.fveeSa

To be able to install the part in the Tevo Tornado V-Slot, you must remove the screws from the V-Slot on the right side. Exercise a slight bending of the support piece and while holding the flexion slowly slide it into the V-Slot and then release. You can add a M3-M5 screw fitted with a T-nut.

The leds are connected in parallel (12-24v) directly on the power supply (24v-12v not 110-220v)

For the piece to be solid, I advise 90% infill.

Within a week after mounting the K8403 LED option of the Velleman Vertex K8400 the double sided tape started to detach and the LED strips were falling down. I decided to make some clips in 3D Builder and print them. First step was to make 8 clips with a 45 degrees angle (as seen by another design somewhere). These were OK for the left and right side but for the front and back side they were to low preventing the X movements. I made substitutes for the front side and back side with 90 degrees (downwards) light direction. Take care that the one at the back/right side is moved as far as possible to the right since otherwise it collides with the print-head when this moves to the home position. Print with 50% infill to make the clips rigid. Note that the clips still require the metal clamps to which the double sided adhesive tape was to be attached. Without these clamps the LED strips will probably fall out.

title: Countersink grinding Attachment for D-Bitgrinder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a countersink sharpening attachment for a D-Bit grinder.
It fits on the HMB U3.

Turn yourself a 8mm piece of steel with 120° cone on one end, on the other a M5 outer thread. This is your Settingping. The Settingpin runs in the V-Grooves. These are helical, so a axial movement feeds your countersink when turning the spindle.
When clamping the Countersink, bring the settingpin in contact with a groove.
Turn the spindle anti-clockwise until the settingpin reaches the end of the groove. Then align your countersink ( left hand Cuttingedge ) to be parallel to the Dovetailjoint of the grindingfixture. ( look pictures for better understanding ).

Dres your wheel before grinding! The countersinks are not ground by swinging the axis, the are ground by plungin into the grindingwheel. Errors on the wheel will occure onto the countersink!

Lower Axis 5°
Upper Axis 45°.

Grinding only by feeding the spindlemicometer, not the micrometer that feed´s the bar where yout Tool sits on.

Greeting in horrible english from Germany,

Thomas

description.text:
This is a remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2528734 , which is a usable design. I just felt I wanted a 30 rd loader with a tray that worked well. Although the tray supplied with the original might work on the 15rd design, it falls flat with the larger design. The tray design I include is able to accept a 20 round box for quick fills. In addition, I added a retainer for the magazine, and split the rail in half for printing on any printer with 200 x 200 bed. I also removed the name from the original and added some cut outs... to save printing time and material.
when you glue this together, I suggest epoxy and drilling some small holes to bound it better..I did not add any glue locking grooves as drilling a few 1/8 inch holes takes under a minute if you go slow... and works just as well.

Finally, keep in mind the retainer is very snug... you might want to scale it up a fraction.. although I felt it was great for the poly mags I use... with just a few seconds of cleanup..

title: SVG to OpenSCAD Bezier - InkScape extension

description.text:
This InkScape extension (plugin) can be used to convert any SVG files to native OpenSCAD code, with full Bezier support. The global variable $fn can be used to tweak the resolution of the curves.

Generated OpenSCAD files contains a stripped down version of my OpenSCAD Bezier library:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2170645

The Cat SVG file used for the demonstration of the library is from:
https://www.onlinewebfonts.com/icon/74146

[2018-02-25] Check if element is empty before adding it to the OpenSCAD file

[2018-03-01] Re-uploaded the ZIP file. Fixed issues with holes. Unfortunately, I can't use the polygon drawing direction to determine if the polygon is a hole or not because the simplepath library do not respect the drawing direction when converting paths. I had to use a logic of "Paths inside path are holes". There is still a possibility of some SVG files not converting well, but they are exception cases that are very unlikely to happen.

[2018-03-03] Fixed bug caused by polygons composed of a single point.

Installation
  1. Download the included Zip file
  2. Extract its content
  3. Copy the 2 extracted files in InkScape extensions folder:
    Linux & Mac OSX: ~/.config/inkscape/extensions/
    Windows: C:/Program Files/Inkscape/share/extensions
Usage
  1. Open any SVG file in InkScape
  2. File > Save as
  3. Select file type "OpenSCAD Bezier (*.scad)"
  4. Open the scad file in OpenSCAD
  5. Set the $fn variable to change the precision if desired and extrude the 2D shape

See included photos for more information

Limitations
  • Colours are ignored. The purpose of this tool is to generate STL files which can be 3D printed. Colours are irrelevant for this purpose.
  • Text and strokes are ignored. The SVG document needs to be converted into Path to work with those.
Converting SVG to Path

If you found a SVG file that is not converting properly, try the following:

  1. Open the SVG in InkScape
  2. Select everything (Ctrl + A)
  3. Convert everything to Path using menu Path > Object to Path (Shift + Ctrl + C)
  4. Save as "OpenSCAD Bezier (*.scad)"

If your SVG file is still not converting properly, please send it to me so I can reproduce the issue and fix it in the library.

comments.text:
Thanks for the suggestion,
I like that extension because it is as simple as it can get for the user. It give you a direct representation of your SVG file, in OpenSCAD. Not configuration, no option, simply "Save as" and you are done. That was one of my goal when developing it so I would like to keep it this way. Of course, once in OpenSCAD, you can do what you want with the 2D shape. You can scale it up of down as much as you want. The conversion is somewhat lossless in the sense that the bezier curves are actually saved in the OpenSCAD file.

English:

I designed this modular shelfing system for a quick and easy printing. If you want to hide the litte gaps, i also designed L and U profiles to create a smooth look.
This version is dimensioned for 16 mm ( 5/8 ") panels.
To measure the panels subtract 20 mm of the middle to middle measurement of the conectors.
You can adjust the length of the profiles (only if you want to use them) in your slicer.
To reeinforce your connectors cast something in the hollow part. I could recommend epoxy resin or plaster.
Mirror the t-Piece in your slicer to get the right one.
If you want to have another type of connector please comment.

Deutsch:

Ich entwarf dieses modulare Regalsystem für einen schnellen und einfachen Druck. Wenn Sie die Lücken verkleiden möchten, können Sie die L, und U-Profile dazu verwenden.
Diese Version ist für 16 mm Platten ausgelegt. Sie können die Verbinder sicher auch über die Sklierung im Slicer für eine stärkere Platte anpassen (bei dünneren Platten werden die Senkbohrungen warscheinlich zu klein)
Das Zuschnittsmaß für die Holzplatte ist 20 mm kleiner als das Mittenmaß ziwschen den Verbindern.
Sie können die Länge der Profile (nur wenn Sie Sie verwenden möchten) in Ihrem Slicer anpassen.
Die Verbinder können in den dafür vorgesehenen Aussparungen mit Epoxydharz oder Gips o.ä. ausgegossen werden um sie zu verstärken. Dies reduziert die Druckzeit maßgeblich.
Der T-Verbinder mit Fuß kann im Slicer gespiegelt werden um das rechte Stück zu bekommen.
Wenn Sie sich weitere Verbinder wünschen einfach in die Kommentare schreiben.

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

15

Notes:

I designed this modular shelfing system for a quick and easy printing. If you want to hide the litte gaps, i also designed L and U profiles to create a smoot look.
This version is dimensioned for 16 mm ( 5/8 ") panels.
To measure the panels subtract 20 mm of the middle to middle measurement of the conectors.
You can adjust the length of the profiles (only if you want to use them) in your slicer.
To reeinforce your connectors cast something in the hollow part. I could recommend epoxy resin or plaster.

Ich entwarf dieses modulare Regalsystem für einen schnellen und einfachen Druck. Wenn Sie die Lücken verkleiden möchten, können Sie die L, und U-Profile dazu verwenden.
Diese Version ist für 16 mm Platten ausgelegt. Sie können die Verbinder sicher auch über die Sklierung im Slicer für eine stärkere Platte anpassen (bei dünneren Platten werden die Senkbohrungen warscheinlich zu klein)
Das Zuschnittsmaß für die Holzplatte ist 20 mm kleiner als das Mittenmaß ziwschen den Verbindern.
Sie können die Länge der Profile (nur wenn Sie Sie verwenden möchten) in Ihrem Slicer anpassen.
Die Verbinder können in den dafür vorgesehenen Aussparungen mit Epoxydharz oder Gips o.ä. ausgegossen werden um sie zu verstärken. Dies reduziert die Druckzeit maßgeblich.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dxTkRNFzo7D

title: Spare Tire Holder for M416 Trailer

description.text:
Not actually a remix, but an add-on to ossums nice M416 Trailer (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2055193)
I wanted to have a spare tire at the trailer without drilling or modifying it permanently.
So here is my solution: a clip-on spare tire holder!
It fits perfectly to the front or rear walls of the trailer tub, or even on both!
Just slide it on the wall, a kind of "tongue-and-groove" on the inner side of the holder secures it tight but still easy to remove.
The actual holder piece is designed to adapt to standard 1/10scale rims with a 12mm hex. There is a hole in it to screw a 3mm self-tapping screw ("tamiya style") in it.

If you like it and even print it, i would love to see some makes!

Just finished, using the same clip: The jerry-can-holder:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2805895

description.text:
Lovely original thing. But my printer is quite short on free space in this area : I have already added a fan "door" modification.

Plus I wanted to add an Y chain, thus I had requirements that were not satisfied with original thing :

  • make sure the filament would not hit the chain, thus move upper the filament guide
  • make the guide "easily unmountable", just in case ... (cold pull that I stil can not achieve, even when puting force like a troll) (or just stuck filament in the hothead)
  • add an easy non straight insert cut for the filament, because when it's already in the hotead, I really don't want to remove it ...

don't FORCE when trying to plug the 2 parts together : if it does not fit, just sand a bit

Rotate the file, seems that I did not get it right before exporting to STL.

title: CoreXY Laser engraver
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Introduction

Some time ago I built a small DVD-Laser engraver but it wasn't really usable. Now this new one became reality by chance. When I upgraded my 3D printer Prusa i3 MK2 to the newer MK2/S version I had a few spare parts, namely linear rods and bearings. Additionally, a 1 W blue laser from eBay was lying around unused... this is the result. ;-)

Disclaimer

This is the obligatory warning. Lasers with such high powers are dangerous and can burn or blind you, even from reflections. Don't attempt to build this if you are not familiar with high power lasers.
Good quality laser protection goggles are a must! Don't use cheap ones. And always wear them! Beware that the laser might turn on unexpectedly when the Arduino is booting (it shouldn't, but don't rely on it).

Design specs

With the spare Prusa linear rods (370 mm and 330 mm) this engraver has a usable work area of 210x220 mm. You might even be able to get a few millimetres more.
The CoreXY system is loosely inspired by other systems, especially the excellent 3D printers Hypercube by Tech2C and Hypercube Evolution by SCOTT_3D. Some other details are also modeled after these printers, such as the belt spanner system on the X carriage.
While these two systems guide their belt on the inside of the printer I decided to move the belts on the outside to get the most usable area. Instead of proper belt pulleys or idlers I used 625 ZZ ball bearings to divert the belt. For now this is working fine.

The limit switches on the X carriage were originally supposed to be triggered by the Y carriage itself. However, when the switches finally arrived they differed from the my 3D model so the additional switch activators were added... it's not elegant, but works. ;-)

Software

The engraver is controlled by an Arduino Mega + Ramps 1.4 board running GRBL 1.1f. These were spare parts I had in my drawer and I wasn't aware of the Arduino CNC shield when I began this build. Plus, the Ramps board seemed like an excellent choice. However, in retrospect, I would not use this board for GRBL again. There are several drawbacks compared the regular CNC shield.

  • no Hardware limits (the limit switches are placed on pins that are not available for external interrupts)
  • the spindle PWM defaults to a 12 V output. The laser driver however expects a 5 V TTL signal for power control (solved with a small GRBL patch)

Be aware that the GRBL version for the Arduino Mega has an issue when homing a CoreXY machine. It's axis locking mechanism prevents both motors to be moved at the same time when homing, i.e. the machine will move diagonally. There's a quick-fix available.

The modifications I made to GRBL are available in this fork on GitHub:
GRBL CoreXY Laser engraver

Parts list

In addition to the printed parts you'll need the following parts, too. If anything is missing please let me know.

Electronics:

  • 1x Arduino Mega / Uno
  • 1x Ramps / Arduino CNC Shield
  • 2x Pololu Stepper driver (A4498, DRV8825, SilentStepStick)
  • 4x Endstops (Makerbot)
  • 1x Laser with TTL driver
  • 1x Power supply (e.g. old ATX)
  • 1x Fan 12V (for the laser)
  • 2x Nema 17 stepper motor

Mechanics:

  • 2x 8mm Rod, 370 mm (Y axis)
  • 2x 8mm Rod, 330 mm (X axis)
  • 8x LM8UU linear bearing
  • 16x Ball bearing 625 ZZ
  • 6x 5mm steel rod, 40 mm
  • 2x GT2 Pulley, 20 teeth
  • ca. 4m GT2 belt
  • 2x Aluminum profile, 30x30 B (8 mm slot), 325 mm
  • 4x Aluminum profile, 30x30 B (8 mm slot), 100 mm
  • 2x Aluminum profile, 30x60 B (8 mm slot), 360 mm
  • 12x Corner mounting brackets 30x30
  • M6 T-slot nuts
  • M6x12 screws
  • M3x16 countersunk head
  • M3x16 head cap screw
  • M3x20 head cap screw
  • M3x25 head cap screw
  • TP screws, 2.5 mm (endstops, Arduino mounting)
  • M3 square nuts
  • M3 hex nuts

Note: The 5 mm linear rods I bought from eBay to mount the bearings had to be sanded down a bit to fit. Your mileage might vary.

comments.text:
how powerful of a power supply does this need
thanks
comments.author: zboy_zboy

comments.text: It doesn't need to be very powerful, it mostly depends on your motors. Regular Nema17 motors are rated at 2 A and driven with 12 V, so you need about 25 W for each. With the laser and the Arduino etc. you should be fine with 75 W, or even less.
comments.author: zboy_zboy

comments.text:
Hi, nice work.
How much power does your laser diode have and is it able to cut thin wood?
comments.author: bnb

comments.text:
Thanks!
It's a 1 W diode and can only cut paper and such. To properly cut wood you'd need several watts... sooner or later I will upgrade, though.

What I would change, the height of the edges should be larger.
And they should be straight instead of concave.
Just like the Aluminium GT2 pulleys are.

title: ES120/ES121 Finger Control Lever Adapter Mod
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
WARNING - this is a work in progress.

This is designed to let you run your ES120/ES121 electronic screwdriver by depressing a lever on the side allowing for finer control when holding the screwdriver at the tip.

Print it using 0.1mm layer height and use a M3 nylon screw/nut to hold it in place. The band will be a snug fit on the screwdriver when nipped up.

Use an emery board/sandpaper on the button depressor under the lever until the lever presses the button at the right position for you. I removed a lot of material so that the button is depressed just before the lever touches the screwdriver so it can't exert too much pressure on the switch.

Happy screwdriver-ing!

title: Easy Universal Z-Braces for CR-10 / S / S4 / S5

description.text:
For the longest time I've been looking for z-braces for the CR-10 with parts that are easy to print and require minimal material. I also wanted them to be easy to assemble and mount with parts that can be found in every hardware store. Just the other day I had yet to find any until William Weston showed me some that he had put together. Inspired by his design I set out to create my own. I then printed them, cut some rods to length and installed them. So far it seems to work really well.

These should also work perfectly fine on different sized CR-10 and I plan on installing them on my S5 soon as well. If you decide to try it on another size, please let us know what rod length you used.

Important: If you're like me and use a capacitive probe for bed leveling the maximum build height will be reduced to 380mm. I haven't tested this with a BLTouch but it should not impact the build height, just as if you're using manual leveling.

What you'll need to buy
  • 2x 60cm M10 threaded rods
  • 4x M4x10 screws
  • 2x M4x15 screws
  • 2x M5x12 screws
  • 4x M4 T-slot nuts
  • 8x M10 nuts
  • 2x M4 nuts
Optional things
  • Cable sleeving
  • Shrink tubing
Tools required

You'll need a tap with M4/M5 pieces to tap holes in the printed parts. The same M5 piece will also be used to tap the holes in the aluminum extrusions on the bottom of the frame.

Enjoy, and please use the make functionality to upload an image if you decide to use this mod on your printer. I hope you'll like this as much as I do.

Printer Brand:

Creality

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I printed with support on just to make sure the holes were clean, but probably prints perfectly fine without supports as well.

Optional: Add some sleeves to make it pretty

In order to cover up the silver rods I went to Biltema (Sweden) and got some 8mm cable sleeving and shrink tubing. Then I tried several times before getting the measurements on and simply put on the tubing. Done!
I designed these parts using Autodesk Fusion 360.

title: Airsoft Vortex Block for 1-1/4 in SCH 40 pipe

description.text:
This is designed to be a one-piece vortex block for airsoft use. This is the kind used for the EE-05 "Montag" Flamethrower as seen on our airsoft teams facebook page. https://www.facebook.com/pg/EEskunkworks/photos/?tab=album&album_id=2048200882058318

the air inlet hole is 0.32 inches in diameter (to be able to be tapped - just be sure to use enough perimeters), and the outlet hole is designed to be a loose fit for standard AEG barrels, suggested to use Epoxy to make the barrel stay in place.

This vortex block is designed to fit inside 1-1/4 inch Schedule 40 PVC pipe. (measuring 1.38 inches inner diameter)

Vortex blocks don't need to deal with much stress or anything so reccomended settings are 2 or more perimeters, with at least 15% infill. we've generally stuck to 3 perimeters and 20% infill.

title: Radial nozzle fan assembly for E3D V6

description.text:
I made a radial nozzle fan assembly for the popular E3D V6 hotend. This nozzle fan design greatly improves your printers performance in terms of print detail and accuracy as well as bridging gaps.

In addition to your E3D V6 and the 3D printed parts, you will need the following hardware to build the fan assembly:

  • 1 x radial cooling fan (5015)
  • 2 x M4 25mm bolts
  • 2 x M4 lock nuts
  • 4 x M3 20mm bolts (low profile socket button/dome head)
  • Glue (for attaching radial fan duct to the radial fan)

Printer:

Archer - An extendable all metal 3D printer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print time: 1 hour (100% infill, print speed 3000 mm/min)

I recommend printing the bracket and fan duct using 100% infill for strength and durability.

There is no need to use supports for the fan duct if you print it on its side, Your printer should be able to bridge the gaps. Plus removing supports from inside the duct would be impractical.

title: Superman - Man of Steel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Superman sculpture based on Henry Cavill's Superman. No mustache version...sorry about that ;)

As a big comic fan I really wanted a nice looking Superman statue and...If you want something, don't wait for someone else to do it for you! Sculpted in Mudbox and 3DS max. Overall pleased with the model except the cape. I tried to scult it in Mudbox but after a while I gave up and instead used Cloth simulation in 3ds max with better result. This however resulted in a very thin non-printable cape so I had to thicken it which made it quite ugly on the inside, but the outside is nice at least;)

I've uploaded multiple versions so you can choose which one to print.

  1. Splitted model, rotate the parts so they lay flat on the print surface and print with support. It has a hole on the back where you can put a rod. See my make for example of that
  2. Full model without stand. It has a hole on the back as well.
  3. Full model with stand. Left foot has a small connection to the stand to give a somewhat feeling that he is floating.

I have ONLY printed the splitted model but if you have a reliable and large printer then I strongly suggest to print the full model to avoid the seams when gluing the pieces together.

Height without the stand is almost 20 cm. It should be possible to scale it down, you just have to try and see for yourself. Will upload a painted version soooooon.

Voron 1.5

No

Yes

0.16

10 %

Support is needed!

I printed mine with a 0.4 nozzle and 60 mm/s. I printed with 0.16 resolution but lower is of course better. Use some infill and at least two shells.

I broke the cap on my glue bottle. I remembered this device based on a product called "Twist-n-Seal". But it would take longer to buy than to print - so here is my version. Use your slicer to stretch or shrink (using "scale") to the general size you need - two versions are shown in the photo from the same STL file. I made mine in TPU and the flex filament version works great but I think a solid version would work OK.

UPDATE 1 - If you print in flex filament like TPU then I suggest 100% fill - not for compression strength but for tensile strength - My original glue stopper broke after multiple pulls out of the container (it was only 30% fill).

Fusion 360

Used Fusion360 to determine the angles needed to modify Bob_East's SCAD file to produce connectors for other polyhedrons.

I've included: Tetrahedron (4 faces), Hexahedron (Cube - 6 faces), Tetratetrahedron (regular octahedron - 8 faces), Dodecahedron (12 faces) and a copy of Bob_East's Icosahedron (20 faces).

The STLs are sized for a round toothpick with a rod diameter of .189 cm, rod socket depth of 1 cm, and a wall thickness of 1 mm (0.1 cm)

title: Canon EOS M tough lens cap

description.text:
I imagine this will fit most of the canon kit type lenes on more cameras than just the EOS M series. Prolly the rebels and 7d and such too. The pictures of the one I made were a lower poly version and this one I uploaded is much smoother. I used the excellent Foxsmart TPU (Sainsmart is also great and on Amazon) for the print. This cap is damn near indestructible in that filament. You could take it off the camera and stomp on it (I have) and it'll just bounce back into shape yet it's very rigid at like a 20% infill. Stays on more reliably than the stock Canon caps but you may want to make the base protecting the lens thicker. I made it about an 1/8" just to cut down on bulk (it was good enough for me), but for more protection of the glass you could do more. The file is linked right here on Tinkercad so you can easily make that change yourself. Use this thing at your own risk I don't guarantee your lens wont get damaged. If you're clueless on Tinkercad just watch a Youtube tutorial. It's super easy I have 6 year olds and 75 year olds that can barely send emails using it to print stuff, so it's pretty intuitive compared to most CAD programs.

description.text: I needed to hang a heat lamp from the top of my spray painting tent. In general, when I print threads I use three perimeter lines and print inside-out to insure that the undersides of the threads print cleanly.

Tumbling smooths things out

I've used this straight off the printer, but if you want to make it look and feel more professional, put it in a rock tumbler with coarse grey abrasive media and a little water for a few days, then move it to white non-abrasive ceramic media for another few days. Polycarbonate attains a beautiful matte sheen when tumbled.

description.text:
Extruder V-Slot mount for Bondtech BMG extruders, with NEMA17 motor. Lets you mount your extruder to the top of a CR-10 for the purposes of using multiple extruders. Not intended for use with the stock CR-10 extruder, but may work with some effort (untested). Works with the normal CR-10 motor however.

Comes with Right Hand and Left Hand versions of the part, in both STL and STEP format for easy editing. Fully in the public domain.

Updated to include version of part with filament sensor mount (rotate the part around and you'll see a little shelf to put the sensor on that lines up with the BondTech extruder inlet)

Updated to use side-mounting for easy access, and a vertical sensor mount option which works better with many sensors

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.4mm nozzle / .15mm layer height

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Due to potential motor heat, you might want to print with PETG or ABS, or something that can survive room temperature + 80C.

Mounting Instructions

First, press fit two M3 hex nuts into the side opposite the extruder. You will need to do this with a pair of pliers as i have made the hex holes a very tight fit, so the nuts don't fall out while mounting.

Leave the other two hex holes empty on the other side (opposite the motor). You will use M3x8 screws for that side.

Mount the motor next, using two M3x8 screws (or M3x6 screws if necessary). Ensure the tooth gear is 4mm down the motor's shaft and tightened with its grub screw along the d-face as appropriate. The spacing here matters because the extruder mount adds 4mm to the distance between the motor and the extruder gears. Tighten the M3 screws fully so they sink flush into the hex hole in the mount.

Then, mount the extruder, using only two of the screws provided, assuming you are using the recommended Bondtech BMG extruder (http://shop.bondtech.se/en/extruders/bmg-extruder.html), you will not be able to use the third screw, but it should not be necessary for proper operation if you tighten the others fully. These screws will go into the hex nuts you pressed in earlier.

Then you can mount it to the rail using M5x6 screws along with two M5 T nuts.

For the filament sensor version, use two M3x20 screws to mount the filament sensor, with M3 nuts on the underside of the mount. Make sure the filament sensor outlet lines up with the extruder inlet before tightening.

The vertical sensor mount may work better for you depending on where your roll of filament is located. Filament has a curl to it, and some filament sensors will stick if they aren't angled the right way, so the vertical option is provided.
